THIS IS OUR MAIN MANHATTAN MEETUP - mostly casual match play, usually attended by 25-35 players.  Note that there are TWO Manhattan meetups this month.

Please bring a board if you have one, though if you don't, we do have a few extra boards available. New members: introduce yourself to any of the organizers (Rod, Rich, Julia and Lynn); to get you started we'll find someone to pair you up with for your first match. After your first match, please feel free to seek out available players to meet and play, throughout the night, just ask if someone would like to play. 


Click here for information on how we play


Click here for information about our Our Organizers

Our group is FREE; Never a Fee to play, but:


There is a two drink/item minimum during the evening for the great space and time that Josie Woods provides us with.

Closest trains:
Josie Woods is 1 block west of R/W train (8th St. stop) or 2 blocks west of
6 train (Astor stop)

Lastly, if you feel like sharing your appreciation for what we do, you may notice there is a new "Chip in" button on the left of our meetup page.  Anything you might want to contribute to help cover the costs of running this meetup would warm the cockles of our hearts to know you love us :)

results.description:
Updated March 8th, 2015

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

SPRING/SUMMER (Mar - Aug)

As the city warms up we play four times a week. Our main location is Riverside Park, with Morningside as a backup.

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Sundays at 1pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Tuesdays at 6pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)
- Thursdays at 6pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)

Damien
[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

MORNINGSIDE DETAILS

The Morningside location is at the corner of 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue. The best way to get there is to take the B or C local to 110th Street. You can also take the 1 train to 110th street at Broadway and then walk East. We will play at the South end of the baseball field parallel to 110th street so that we're not in the way of the baseball games. Riverside will be our backup if for some reason we need to change locations.

+++

OTHER SEASONS...

WINTER (Nov - Feb)

During the colder months we generally play two times a week depending on weather. Our main location is Riverside Park with Morningside as a backup.

There are two days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (108th and West End - Big Soccer Field)
- Sundays at 1pm, Riverside Park (108th and West End - Big Soccer Field)
*Tuesdays/Thursdays at 6pm games don't last long due to decreasing sunlight.

FALL (Sep - Oct)

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Morningside Park (110th and Manhattan Ave)
- Sundays at 4pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Tuesdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Thursdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)

results.description:
THE STARTUP ROADMAP: 10 profit principles get at the nub of how startups makes consistent profits and how they can help you build an enduring business that produces sustainable profits as well (all attendees will receive The Startup Roadmap booklet ) 


1. Build a Business Based on Your Distinctive Competence
2. Develop and Deliver a Superior Value Proposition
3. Don’t Start Up Until…
4. Take Charge of the Money and Control It
5. Create a Profit-Based Reward Structure
6. Recognize and Hire “Lightning in a Bottle”
7. Create Profit Centers to Scale Your Business
8. Augment Profits with Proprietary Technology
9. Build a Financial War Chest for Strategic Advantage
10. Behave Ethically, and Profits Will Follow

+Comp: Pizza, Soda, Marley Coffee, Hint Essence Water, Bavarian Beer!

Main Speaker:  Ed “Skip” McLaughlin, Entrepreneur & Investor

Skip is an Entrepreneur, Executive, and Author. Founder of four B2B businesses. Investor in start-ups and real estate. Executive with Johnson Controls and Partner at Trammell Crow Company. Regional Marketing Manager at Hewlett-Packard and salesman for IBM. Founded real estate services company United Systems Integrators Corporation (USI) in 1991, grew USI into an Inc 500 Company and sold it to a Fortune 100 company, Johnson Controls in 2005. Became CEO of JCI's Global Workplace Business for the Americas from 2005 to 2007. Honored by Ernst and Young as Entrepreneur of the Year for Business Outsourcing in 2001.Having bootstrapped four companies, Skip will be releasing a new book: "The Purpose Is Profit: Secrets of a Successful Entrepreneur From Startup to Exit."

Rohan Marley, Founder and Chairman

Rohan Marley is the founder and acting chairman of Marley Coffee®, son of Bob Marley, and a passionate entrepreneur. Rooted in the Marley family values of love, passion and social responsibility, Marley Coffee is dedicated to creating a brighter tomorrow for future generations, while building a thriving international business. Rohan is actively involved as ambassador to Water Wise Coffee™, is Vice President of Protecting African Lions (PAL), recently joined Fortune Rookies in Finland and is know as the Govern General of the Marley Family business and supports all family brands. Rohan integrates coffee, tech and charity to encourage social connectivity globally.  You can follow Rohan on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram


Panelist:  Amit Shah, Founder & CEO 


Amit is the founder of AIT International Corp. He is a young entrepreneur who started AIT when he was a sophomore in high school. He started the business with $0.00 and has grown the company into mid-sized company. Recently he received a letter of intent. However, he declined it -- all $10 million -- confident he can grow without taking on any investors at this time.  He aims to build AIT into a market leader. He will be entering his senior year this September and as long as he passes all of his classes, he will continue to expand the company and gain market share at a faster pace!  Still in high school he still oversees the company, manages a team of developers and is responsible for the project management and growth. He says that he wants to be a prime example of "you don't need college to succeed in life". 

Panelist: Bruce Bachenheimer, Professor and Director

Bruce is a Clinical Professor of Management and the Executive Director of the Entrepreneurship Lab at Pace University. He teaches undergraduate and graduate courses, primarily in the areas of entrepreneurship, management and strategy. He is also the organizer of the annual Pace Pitch Contest and Business Plan Competition. He is a member of the Board and past Chair of the New York City Chapter of the MIT Enterprise Forum and has served on the organization’s Global Board. He serves on the Board of Directors & Advisors of LeadAmerica and has served as a consultant to governmental organizations and a variety of new ventures.

Moderator: Kevin Pianko, Partner of WeiserMazars, performs audits of public and private companies and assists them with the financial and operational aspects of their business. He helps clients obtain alternative sources of capital and provides merger and acquisitions, and strategic alliance analysis. Kevin has industry expertise in life sciences, private equity activities, SEC/public companies, technology, manufacturing, professional services, and financial services. He is also a regular on Bloomberg Radio and NBC.

Host: David Carlos, Founder & CTO of Myhomepayge.com

David is the Sexy Technologist, a Tech Geek and Entrepreneur!

EVENT DETAILS - Keep Scrolling Down!

____________________________________________

Please pay PayPal as you RSVP. PAC 12 students and alumni are free at door (Use coupon code PAC12 in your Disruptive Techies bio). 

We need your full name of you and those of your guests for security reasons. For guests send an email to: [masked]

WHEN: October 6, 2015 from 6.15 PM to 8.15 PM

WHERE: Microsoft, 11 Times Square, 8th Avenue 

AGENDA

6:15 to 6:45:  Pizza & Soda thanks to FundingPost,  Beer & Wine, Hint Essence Water and more....

6:45 to 8:15:  Announcements, Panel and Group Discussion

8:15 to 8:30:  Q&A

8:30 to 10:30 Special Disruptive Happy Hour 

If you want to have updates and reminders about the event, you can join as a Member at:

http://www.meetup.com/Disruptive-Technologists-in-NYC/.

Links to the videos of our last three events:

Balancing a Cool Idea with Profitability

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZgFqsE2SeGw&feature=youtu.be

NYC Social Infrastructure & Tech Ecosystem: Are We At An Inflection Point?: 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bbBT9-ZzDJw

Disruptive Technologists in NYC - Internet of Things:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U0f5ochN3LM

About: Disruptive Technologists is an organization dedicated to finding out what makes Disrupters tick – what they are thinking, how they do what they do and then inspire, promote, support, mentor and advise  in order to future Disruption in NYC through tech. We do this through the weekly publication DisruptiveTechnologists.com, monthly panels through our organization Digital Technologists in NYC and through our monthly newsletter. We also report on and cover new Disrupters and attend the hottest events in order to spread their Disruptive words.  We offer an intimate look at this new breed of tech entrepreneurs and their innovative products and services. 

Join us for the event to hear from some of the most qualified, dedicated, and passionate Disrupters in the business.

Curious about coding this fall? Join us for refreshments and a glimpse into our 19-week bootcamp program that transforms beginners into full-stack web developers! 

Thinking about switching careers and becoming a software developer? Interested in learning how to code? Dev Bootcamp is a 19-week intensive program for beginners, dabblers, and those with some prior programming experience. Our monthly open house gives you the inside scoop from Dev Bootcamp students, instructors, and alumni.  

Hear from members of our community about why they chose Dev Bootcamp, what they learned, and what they do after. Hear from staff and instructors about our educational style, resources, and application process. Tour our space and imagine what it would be like to come here and solve problems, build things, and learn something new.

Have you already been accepted to Dev Bootcamp? Join us to hear from our alumni and meet our instructors. Get a feel for what it's like to attend Dev Bootcamp, our curriculum, and our learning environment, and meet other accepted students. 


Agenda:

results.description:
Note: This is a musical performance, not a social gathering like our monthly meeting. 

Seats are limited and your seat is not guaranteed unless you RSVP to the sponsor directly (see contact below) and get a positive response from them. 

In other words:

Step 1: Click the RSVP button here in the group.

Step 2: Send e-mail to [masked] with your first & last name as well as the date you will be going.

What is it?

Deutsches Haus, in collaboration with the Brooklyn Art Song Society, presents Britannica in Deutsch, a musical performance celebrating British song in the work of English composer Benjamin Britten (6 Hölderlin-Fragments Op.61) as well as pieces by the German composers Franz Schubert (3 Shakespeare Lieder), Robert Schumann (from Myrthen, Op. 25), and Richard Strauss (3 OpheliaLieder Op.67).

More info here: http://deutscheshaus.as.nyu.edu/object/io_1439311163699.html


Britannica in Deutsch will be featuring performances by:

Soprano Kristina Bachrac

Tenor Nils Neubert

Pianist Michael Brofman

Pianist Miori Sugiyama

The pieces are sung in German, but English translations will be provided.

Who is hosting the event?

Deutsches Haus @ NYU is the host for this event.  They have staff members on site. 

How do I get there?

N/R - 8th St NYU (3 Blocks)

6 - Astor Place (4 blocks)

B/D/F/M - West 4th St (5-8 Blocks)

Is there a bar / food  available?

No. This is a musical performance. 

How do I register or reserve a seat?

While the event is free, advance registration with the host is required. Please register ASAP by e-mailing [masked] in order to reserve your spot. They will need your first & last name as well as the date of the event to put you on the attendee list.

Why do I have to RSVP twice?

We are trying to add value to the group by offering additional events related to the German culture and language. As we are in the trial phase we are gauging the interest in the group for certain things like concerts, exhibits, and other events. The hosts/organizers/sponsors of those events are not necessarily associated with meetup or our group and therefor have their own RSVP procedures in place which we must follow in order to participate.

Please only RSVP if you mean it and update it if your plans change. It helps more than you might think and is highly appreciated. Thank you!

Thomas

[masked]

[masked]
results.name: Free cultural event: Britannica in Deutsch - Deutsches Haus @ NYU

results.description:
The Earth without bats would be a very different and much poorer place. More than 1,300 species of bats around the world play an ecological role vital to the health of natural ecosystems and human economies. Bats are wonderfully beneficial creatures that provide invaluable services to the world yet they are also among the most misunderstood.  Bats are routinely feared and loathed as sinister denizens of the night.

Learn the truth about these fascinating mammals and the worldwide collaborative work to address the most serious threats facing bats today.

Speaker: Dr. Rodrigo A. Medellin, President

Society for Conservation Biology

**Please remember to email [masked] your RSVP for this meet up. Thank you for your cooperation in this matter.

Ladies, we have a special workshop from a NY Lovestyle Coach Lisa Velazquez.  Here's what she's about.

Lisa Velázquez is the Founder of Lisa Talks Love, where she is The Lovestyle Coach, Sex Therapist/Educator & Keynote Speaker with the heart's desire to Rock The World through LOVE.

Whether you want to learn how to date wise, get over an ex and attract your Mr. Right, Lisa is committed to support female entrepreneurs and business women to get real, get clear and get ready for the love life they desire.  


This work shop will be a great introduction to what she does and how to get started or get assistance on the love path.

Hope you can make it!

-------- A little more about Lovestyle Coach Lisa ------

Lisa is a highly sought-after expert that has been featured in Latina Magazine, New Latina, Pretty Padded Room, Today's Leading Women, Cosmo For Latinas, Proud To Be Latina, Power Women Radio, Urban Latino Radio among others for her inside scoop on modern dating trends, hot safe sex and healthy romantic relationships.

Lisa attended Teachers College, Columbia University for a Masters in Clinical Psychology, and is a Certified Sex Therapist, Sexuality Educator and Facilitator for Preventing Adolescent Pregnancy.

As a thought leader with a global vision, her message Love By Example embodies the belief that when you choose to stand for your love values, you can change the world.

results.description:
This week I am going to see The Martian I will arrive at 6:30 for the 7:0 pm showing. I  have seat E11  If you are coming post your seat #!


Hope to see YOU!  Love, Cassie


Ok who LOVES the movies as much as me? Who has a limited entertainment budget like me? LOL Well this is the event for YOU!

My local theater has discount Tuesday every week and if you sign up online they will even send you a coupon for the concession stand, each week a different one (this weeks is free small popcorn with a drink purchase). They also have those awesome new reclining seats! And you get to choose and pay for your seat in advance so there is no rushing in at the last minute and sitting in the front row and straining your neck!  Here is the link to the theater for more details: http://www.cinemark.com/theatre-detail.aspx?node_id=83854

So here is how it's going to work each week. I will choose a movie when the new schedule goes out (Thur/Fri) and choose the movie and showtime. I will buy my seat online and post what row and number. Those of you who wish to join me can buy your seat near me. There are two ways to buy seats: 1) online in advance is your best bet but there is a $1.25 service fee per ticket unless you buy a gift card at the theater and pre-load it. 2) At the theater no service fee but you really need to driver there in advance if you want seats near us. OR you can just show up that night and sit wherever there is space available.

 Hope to see YOU at the movies!!  Love, Cassie

if you can't make it, no need to post why. We understand and will catch you next time!

results.description:
EVENT DETAILS: Whether you've been working in technology for years or just landed your first developer job, there are always ways in which you can improve your practices and broaden your thinking. At this Tech Talks event, we'll hear from three tremendous women and accomplished technologists on the theme of "Becoming a Better Developer." Topics will range from their own best practices and continued learnings, to how to create a culture of empowered developers. Join us!

SPEAKERS:

Rachel Laycock – Head of Technology (North America) at Thoughtworks

Rachel is the Head of Technology for North America at ThoughtWorks and is based in New York. She has over 12 years of experience in software delivery, having worked on a wide range of technologies and the integration of many disparate systems. At ThoughtWorks, she has coached teams on Agile and Continuous Delivery technical practices. She contributes to and drives the regional technology strategy, and is a conduit between the technical teams on the ground and global technical leadership. She is also a member of the Technical Advisory Board to the CTO, which regularly produces the ThoughtWorks Technology Radar. She is fascinated by problem solving and has discovered that people problems are often more difficult to solve than software ones. 


April Rathe – Head of Risk Technology at AQR Capital Management

April is the Head of Risk Technology at AQR Capital Management and one of the organizers of the Software Craftsmanship NYC Meetup. She has over 15 years experience building software that both drives and enhances business innovation. She coaches and provides training in Agile and engineering practices, helping teams to experiment and gain fluency in new technical practices. She is driven by continuous improvement, challenging the accepted norms in development, and the knowledge that there is always something new to learn.


Cristiana Yambo – Head of App Development NBCUniversal OTS


Cristiana has almost two decades of industry experience in delivering quality software, from apps to web services. She has led teams using Agile and Continuous integration practices to create high levels of efficiency. She is also a member of Women Who Code NYC and teaches beginner developers on how to enter the industry.


SCHEDULE: 

6:30-7:00 – Arrive, eat, mingle

7:00-7:15 – Welcome from Women Who Code & Harry's 

7:15-7:40 – Rachel Laycock: Being a Small, Global, 3000-Person Company    

7:45-8:10 – April Rathe: A Journey in Technical Excellence 

8:15-8:40 – Cristiana Yambo: Perfection and Failure: How to Make Great Software Without Spending Your Life Behind a Desk

8:40-9:00 – Wrap up

Events are intended for people who identify as women, which includes trans women. Our Code of Conduct applies to all events run by Women Who Code, Inc.

HOST:

Harry's is a grooming brand that offers customers high quality products at a fair price.  We are a vertically integrated business meaning we own everything from design to manufacturing to the commerce experience,which we provide directly to consumers through our site, harrys.com.
results.name: Tech Talks: Becoming a Better Developer

results.description:
Even though I love beer, I usually don't schedule back to back meetups, but I just got a note from Jonny, the manager at this place and they are getting in a lot of fall beers at the end of next week and he wanted to make sure the group could come in and sample them.

He had a few dates open where we wouldn't be competing with trivia or other events they are having and this was the one that fit best (one of the nights was the same date I have tickets for "Hamilton" and I was not going to change that!)

So, if you aren't going to the Monday meetup (or if you want beer club two days in a row!) come out down to Gowanus and have some Oktoberfest beers.

Reminder, for some people the map to this place looks funny.   It shows correct for me but that is not the case for everyone.  This is in Gowanus/Park Slope, not Williamsburgh. Most people take the G or the F to Carroll Street.  If you exit that station toward the front of the train, it puts you on Smith/3rd Streets. Make a left on 3rd, walk up two long blocks just over the bridge, and Whole Foods is on the right (they also have a parking lot). The Roof is upstairs (obviously) on the South side of the store, towards the canal.  If you go in the entrace there, the stairs going up are right there.

Hope to see you in Brooklyn!

Cheers,

Bill
results.name: Let's drink beer at a Gowanus Oktoberfest!

results.description:
HashiCorp joins DigitalOcean on a discussion on their new product announcements, Nomad and Otto following HashiConf. 


6:30pm - Food and beverages by SWILL

7:00pm - Mac Browning of DigitalOcean, Bringing Consul to Production

Exploring the turbulent waters of service discovery at DigitalOcean. The tale of deploying consul to 10s of thousands of nodes.


7:30pm - Armon Dadgar, CTO of HashiCorp on Nomad and Otto

HashiCorp is the creator of the open source tools Vagrant, Packer, Terraform, Consul, Serf, Vault, Nomad, and Otto and the commercial product Atlas. Armon Dadgar, the CTO of HashiCorp, will be speaking about the company's vision for application delivery and the design considerations for each of the open source products underneath that vision. 

Nomad and Otto

Nomad is a cluster manager and resource schduler, and Otto is the successor to Vagrant for both development and deployment. 

If you weren't able to get tickets to HashiConf in Portland, this is the perfect event to get caught up on all things HashiCorp. 

8:30pm - Stick around to meet HashiCorp and DigitalOcean.
results.name: Hashicorp: Nomad & Otto new product features

results.description:
Dear Dharma Drink Friends,

Please join us for another fun evening of dinner and discussion at the V-Spot.  V-Spot is a Latin Vegan Kosher restaurant.  (To use this space each participant needs to order one main dish or be charged a $15 seating fee)

BUDDHISM, COMPASSION & SOCIAL ACTIVISM


We had a dinner and discussion on this topic last year.  So much have happened during the past year; we are due for another dinner discussion on this topic.  Buddhism, Compassion, and Social Activism.

------------------------------

“Go forth, o bhikkhus, for the good of the many, for the happiness of the many, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, for the good, for the happiness of gods and men. Let not two go by one way" - Mahavagga, Vinaya Pitaka

The word “Buddhism” tends to conjure images of calm people meditating in quiet, peaceful environments rather than social action. While many students of the buddhadharma have followed the path focused on withdrawn, inward spiritual cultivation, many practitioners have instead chosen to embrace the path of active social engagement.  Even in the time of the Buddha, there was a distinction between those who lived in the forests far from society and those who lived in the middle of cities.  For the second group, there is a long and rich history of Buddhist monastics being socially active by serving as teachers, overseeing schools, and running hospitals.

More recently, the Humanistic Buddhist movement that began in the early 1900s in China heavily influenced the Engaged Buddhist movement, which was pioneered by Thich Nhat Hanh in the 1960s and 1970s. The activist culture of this era continues to influence many Buddhist-inspired outreach activities around the world. In Asia, many socially engaged Buddhist groups, particularly those from Taiwan, have become very prominent and are active internationally.  Here in New York Buddhist Global Relief is actively making a difference.

Join us for an evening of dinner and discussion as we explore the relationship between Buddhism and social activism. Some of our discussion points include:

-Is it better to focus on improving oneself before becoming socially engaged or

-Can social engagement itself be a way to practice the Buddha’s teachings? 

-What role does/can social engagement/outreach play in our own practice?

-Are there activities that can potentially conflict with Buddhist teachings (for example protests or civil disobedience)?

-What kind of activities are current Buddhist organizations engaged in and is it enough? If not, what’s lacking?

Further reading:

-Wikipedia: Humanistic Buddhism

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanistic_Buddhism

-“Buddhism and Social Action: An Exploration”. by Ken Jones

http://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/jones/wheel285.html

results.description:
Dear Friends,

Please join us for another fun evening of dinner and discussion at the V-Spot.  V-Spot is a Latin Vegan Kosher restaurant.  (To use this space each participant needs to order one main dish or be charged a $15 seating fee)

BUDDHISM, COMPASSION & SOCIAL ACTIVISM 

We had a dinner and discussion on this topic last year.  So much have happened during the past year; we are due for another dinner discussion on this topic.  Buddhism, Compassion, and Social Activism.

------------------------------

“Go forth, o bhikkhus, for the good of the many, for the happiness of the many, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, for the good, for the happiness of gods and men. Let not two go by one way" - Mahavagga, Vinaya Pitaka

The word “Buddhism” tends to conjure images of calm people meditating in quiet, peaceful environments rather than social action. While many students of the buddhadharma have followed the path focused on withdrawn, inward spiritual cultivation, many practitioners have instead chosen to embrace the path of active social engagement.  Even in the time of the Buddha, there was a distinction between those who lived in the forests far from society and those who lived in the middle of cities.  For the second group, there is a long and rich history of Buddhist monastics being socially active by serving as teachers, overseeing schools, and running hospitals.

More recently, the Humanistic Buddhist movement that began in the early 1900s in China heavily influenced the Engaged Buddhist movement, which was pioneered by Thich Nhat Hanh in the 1960s and 1970s. The activist culture of this era continues to influence many Buddhist-inspired outreach activities around the world. In Asia, many socially engaged Buddhist groups, particularly those from Taiwan, have become very prominent and are active internationally.  Here in New York Buddhist Global Relief is actively making a difference.

Join us for an evening of dinner and discussion as we explore the relationship between Buddhism and social activism. Some of our discussion points include:

-Is it better to focus on improving oneself before becoming socially engaged or

-Can social engagement itself be a way to practice the Buddha’s teachings? 

-What role does/can social engagement/outreach play in our own practice?

-Are there activities that can potentially conflict with Buddhist teachings (for example protests or civil disobedience)?

-What kind of activities are current Buddhist organizations engaged in and is it enough? If not, what’s lacking?

Further reading:

-Wikipedia: Humanistic Buddhism

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanistic_Buddhism

-“Buddhism and Social Action: An Exploration”. by Ken Jones

http://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/jones/wheel285.html

-BBC: “Meeting Taiwan’s New Age Buddhists”

http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-25772194

-Shambhala Sun: “In Engaged Buddhism, Peace Begins With You”

http://www.shambhalasun.com/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=1579&Itemid=0&limit=1&limitstart=0

-Buddhadharma: “A Challenge to Buddhists” by Bhikkhu Bodhi

http://archive.thebuddhadharma.com/issues/2007/fall/commentary.php

Groups of interests:

-Buddhist Global Relief.  https://buddhistglobalrelief.org

-Tzu Chi. http://www.tzuchi.us/

-Buddhist Peace Fellowship.  http://www.buddhistpeacefellowship.org/welcome-to-bpf/

-------

Note: we are here to share and provide others with opportunity to speak.  Also we need to be cognizant not to preach or solicit.

Look forward to meeting everyone,

_/|\_

Eddie

results.description:
Finding things that have moved similarly in the past can be a key part of predicting how things will move in the future. However, like most analysis techniques, correlation can fail when certain underlying conditions are not met. 

This lecture will cover correlation, how it is used in finance, and how you can use it to improve trading algorithms.

This talk is part of Quantopian’s Lecture Series. All lecture materials can be found at: www.quantopian.com/lectures.

Pizza and beverages will be provided by Quantopian.

Speaker Details:

Delaney Granizo-Mackenzie is an engineer at Quantopian who focuses on how Quantopian can be used as a teaching tool. 

After studying computer science at Princeton, Delaney joined Quantopian in 2014. Since then he has led successful course integrations at MIT Sloan and Stanford, and is working with over 20 courses for this fall. Delaney is using his experience and feedback from professors to build a quantitative finance curriculum focusing on best statistical practices to be offered for free. Delaney’s background includes 7 years of academic research at a bioinformatics lab, and a strong focus on statistics and machine learning.
results.name: The Good, the Bad, and the Correlated

THIS IS THE MEETUP FOR YOU. We'll be tackling questions like: Are you drawing comics? When are you going to draw comics? Why aren't you drawing comics right this moment? And so on and so forth. The answer to all these questions is: SHUT UP AND DRAW COMICS.

Drop on by, bring a friend, grab a beer or coffee, say hello, chat if you want, but DRAW COMICS.

We have a monthly meet and greet hangout meetup, and we also schedule drawing days, sketch days, convention visits, museum trips, whatever. If you have an idea for a meetup or a location you'd like to suggest, let me know!

For everyone who's been coming regularly, THANK YOU!! And newcomers - please feel free to come and join. Our group is diverse, energizing, and judgment-free. Finally, we would like to humbly ask that you consider pitching in $1 or $2 (only if you come a second+ time - not for newcomers) - it helps leverage the monthly Meetup website payment.

results.description:
BACK BY POPULAR DEMAND!

Fullstack's JavaScript Jumpstart is a two-week night course that teaches the "ABCs" of programming and JavaScript.

WHO IS THIS COURSE FOR? 

It's designed for students with little programming experience who want to get a "jumpstart" on their journey toward becoming a Fullstack developer. This course is also a great way to prepare for Fullstack Academy's admissions interviews. 

HOW IS THE COURSE STRUCTURED? WHAT IS THE SCHEDULE? 

The course will run over 3 evenings in two weeks. The three sessions will cover JavaScript fundamentals. Each concept will be covered by a practical hands-on workshop. You'll develop core programming skills and use them to build a cool final project, which will be created remotely after the 3rd class.  There will also be remote work to be completed during a portion of the off-nights.

HOW SHOULD I PREPARE FOR JUMPSTART?

All students will need to complete approximately 4-5 hours of pre-work before the first class.  Students are also required to bring their own laptop.

IS JAVASCRIPT JUMPSTART AN IN-PERSON OR REMOTE CLASS?

Both! There are two options for attending this course:

Live/In-Person - Jumpstart is taught at Fullstack Academy's campus in downtown NYC. Choose this option to attend all 3 evenings in-person, get in-person instruction and TA assistance, and see the Fullstack campus.

Remote/Online - If you can't make it to the Fullstack campus, you can attend JavaScript Jumpstart remotely. All lectures will be video-streamed, and workshop assistance will be available for remote students.

HOW MUCH DOES THE COURSE COST?

Tuition for this course is $295

HOW CAN I REGISTER? 

You must register through Eventbrite to secure a spot in the class. Head to the link below to signup for the class. Exclusively for our Meetup group members - Use the coupon code "jsmeetup" to take 15% off the price!

**Event Signup Link:www.october-javascript-jumpstart.eventbrite.com**

** More Info:JSNP Class Details** 


Class space is limited, sign up today to secure your spot!

Course Schedule: 6:30pm - 9pm, All Classes

Day 1: Tuesday Oct. 6, 2015

Day 2: Thursday Oct. 8, 2015

Day 3: Tuesday  Oct 13, 2015
results.name: JavaScript Jumpstart October 2015

results.description:
Has this ever happened to you?

You spend three to four hours emailing and talking with a prospective client and put in more time writing a proposal. Then, not long after you send it, your prospect tells you he gave the project to someone else.

Or worse, your once hot lead says, "No thanks!" Then...a month later you discover that they used your concept and ideas.

Have you had a similar experience?

Would you like to prevent it from happening again?

Every month I receive four to five emails and calls from creative professionals seeking advice and help with prospects, clients and projects that have gone sour.

Most of their questions are about issues that I haven't had a problem with for at least a dozen years. To help combat these pitfalls, this presentation focuses on:

* How to get paid what you're worth

* How to stop prospective clients from stealing your ideas and knowledge

* How to get paid on time for every dollar you're owed

* How to detect a bad client before you invest much time in them

* How to get paid to write project proposals

* More best practices for business success

AGENDA

Increasing your happiness and income from your freelance career:

6:30pm - networking and refreshments


7:00pm - discussion with lots of Q&A

8:30pm - networking and more Q&A

This meetup is perfect for anyone who would like to be successful selling WordPress design/development, copywriters, graphic artists, photographers, social media consultants, videographers, etc.

SPEAKER

D.K. Smith is a serial entrepreneur who teaches in Pratt Institute's Certificate in Design Entrepreneurship program, and formerly taught "Business and Marketing" at the Southeast Center for the Arts in Atlanta.

D.K. is managing director of Brooklyn Innovation Center's startup accelerator. He is a judge for the Brooklyn Public Library’s PowerUP! business plan competition. He's also a startup mentor for the NYC BigApps civic tech competition.

D.K. co-founded WPSecurity.com in 2009 and Dotcom Diligence in 2008 to provide due diligence services to for angels and VCs.  In 1998 he founded GetCustomers.com conversion and monetization firm, and sold two creative businesses prior to that.

OUR SPONSOR

We're happy to announce that WeWork is the new home of the Brooklyn Startups Meetup! 

WeWork provides small businesses, startups, and freelancers with the workspace, community, and services they need to make a life, not just a living. From weekly events, personalized support, flexibility, and access to thousands of other members around the world, WeWork is the perfect place to grow your business in 2015 and beyond. Their core values and commitment to Brooklyn make this an excellent collaboration! 

Click here for info on joining WeWork's community of creators in downtown Brooklyn.

results.description:
Curious about coding? Ever wonder how Web browsers interface with servers to bring you actual websites? Want to learn face-to-face with others in a welcoming community?

Join us for an introductory dive into Ruby, a beginner-friendly language used on servers in backend web development (i.e., the stuff that goes on between entering a URL and getting a web page back).

In this workshop, we will walk you through the basics of the Ruby language and how to use it to set up a basic web server. We’ll cover:

* All the tools you need to get up, running and coding with Ruby

* Ruby syntax for basic programming concepts like variables, loops, methods, strings, arrays and hashes

* The basics of how the World Wide Web works under the hood

* Setting up a simple web server and sending HTML pages to a browser

* Using your server to interact with Twitter via its API

* Available resources if you’d like to continue learning

This event is open to adult (18+) beginners and is an introduction to concepts covered more deeply in the immersive program. Please bring your own laptop (Mac, PC or Chromebook). Light snacks will be provided. 

Prerequisite: A basic understanding of HTML/CSS and Ruby (e.g. topics covered in Codecademy’s HTML & CSS and Ruby</a> tracks).


Build your programming knowledge independently or collectively in our workshop series: 

<a href="http://www.meetup.com/DBC-NYC/events/224449450/">HTML/CSS for Beginners - evening workshop [9/29 from 6:30-9pm] 
Javascript for Beginners - evening workshop [10/1 from 6:30-9:30pm] 
Ruby for Beginners - evening workshop [10/6 from 6:30-9:30pm] 
Full Stack Development - day long weekend workshop [10/10 from 10am-6pm]<a href="http://www.meetup.com/DBC-NYC/events/224450141"></a>

results.description:
Come on out and enjoy a night of food drink, conversation and a little friendly competition! Test your skills as New York Social Network Founder Dave Cervini hosts a fun evening that will have you thinking, laughing and learning about pop culture, music, TV, Movie, History, NYC and more.

Most questions are easy and others you may have to rely on your teammates for help. Come alone or with a friend. Even if you think you don’t know much trivia, it is still a great way to meet others in the group. We will have special sections set aside for NYSN members to meet and team up.  Pay as you go for food and drink. There are several rounds and prizes awarded for each round!

Can I come alone? Yes! If you do not know anyone there we will introduce you to others and make you part of teams.

What should I wear? Most come from work but The Firehouse is a pub with a very casual atmosphere.

Can I eat there? The Firehouse is known for it's wings. But they also have burgers, quesadillas, veggie sandwiches, salads, pizza, burrito's and more. If you want to eat with the group, plan to get there around 7pm.

How long does it last? We have 3 rounds of 15 questions each.  The trivia usually lasts until about 9:30pm.  After that some stayb and socialize and other head home.

How do I get there? It is near the corner of west 85th and Columbus Avenue.  The B,C stop a block away at CPW and 86th and the #1 stops at B'way and 86th.

This event is being hosted by The New York Social Network  WWW.NEWYORKSOCIALNETWORK.COM  and several of their partner Meet Up Groups.  The number of RSVP’s below reflect only a portion of those attending.  Please only sign up for this event if you are serious about attending. (We have a 3 flakes and you’re out rule). If you have any questions regarding this or any of our events please contact Dave Cervini directly at [masked] or call[masked]

results.description:
Come on out and enjoy a night of food drink, conversation and a little friendly competition! Test your skills as New York Social Network Founder Dave Cervini hosts a fun evening that will have you thinking, laughing and learning about pop culture, music, TV, Movie, History, NYC and more.

Most questions are easy and others you may have to rely on your teammates for help. Come alone or with a friend. Even if you think you don’t know much trivia, it is still a great way to meet others in the group. We will have special sections set aside for NYSN members to meet and team up.  Pay as you go for food and drink. There are several rounds and prizes awarded for each round!

Can I come alone? Yes! If you do not know anyone there we will introduce you to others and make you part of teams.

What should I wear? Most come from work but The Firehouse is a pub with a very casual atmosphere.

Can I eat there? The Firehouse is known for it's wings. But they also have burgers, quesadillas, veggie sandwiches, salads, pizza, burrito's and more. If you want to eat with the group, plan to get there around 7pm.

How long does it last? We have 3 rounds of 15 questions each.  The trivia usually lasts until about 9:30pm.  After that some stayb and socialize and other head home.

How do I get there? It is near the corner of west 85th and Columbus Avenue.  The B,C stop a block away at CPW and 86th and the #1 stops at B'way and 86th.

This event is being hosted by The New York Social Network  WWW.NEWYORKSOCIALNETWORK.COM  and several of their partner Meet Up Groups.  The number of RSVP’s below reflect only a portion of those attending.  Please only sign up for this event if you are serious about attending. results.description:
If you are interested in understanding how to set-up a company the right way, then join us for Startup Legal. Learn from a top local attorney the key things that you need to know to start your company. What is the most appropriate type of company to start? How do you deal with cofounders, initial team members and employees? What agreements should you have in place when you start, and what pitfalls should you avoid?

Speaker:

- Joe Daniels  (Sheppard Mullin LLP)

Mr. Daniels represents startup to publicly-held technology, life science and consumer companies, venture capital and private equity funds and investment banks in a wide range of seed and venture financings, mergers and acquisitions, IPOs and other public offerings. He regularly advises a broad range of startups, venture-backed companies and VC funds, and has led hundreds of venture and strategic financing transactions. Mr. Daniels has helped companies and private equity firms handle over $5 billion of merger, acquisition and disposition transactions. Additionally, he has represented issuers and underwriters in more than 25 IPOs and follow-on public offerings involving companies in the technology, life sciences and consumer sectors, including leading investment banks such as Credit Suisse, Morgan Stanley and Oppenheimer.

Mr. Daniels also serves as outside general counsel for numerous companies, assisting them with everything from day-to-day business transactions to multinational strategic alliance transactions ranging from technology and distribution partnerships to joint ventures. He focuses on representing clients involved in high-growth sectors, and has experience with a broad range of industries, including adtech, biotech, cleantech, consumer, digital media, ecommerce, energy, Internet of Things, Fintech/financial services, life sciences, mobile, semiconductor, software, UAVs and telecommunications.

Who Should Attend?
• Anyone interested in incorporating an early-stage company
• Anyone that wants an understanding of basic corporate law
• Anyone who has questions about Founder Institute legal agreements

What are some of the Topics?
• When should you incorporate your company
• What are the steps to incorporate a business
• What agreements should you understand as a Founder
• How do you handle cofounders, team memebers and employees
• What are the Founder Institute agreements and the Shared Liquidity Pool
• and more...

What is the Agenda?
• Welcome and Socializing
• Overview of Startup Legal
• Question and Answer
• Introduction to the Founder Institute
• Discussion and Drinks at a Local Bar or Restaurant

This event is free to attend. Join us for a fun evening! For more free startup events, visit http://FI.co/events.
results.name: Startup Legal 101

In this group, you'll learn new ways of communicating in order to share more vulnerably and openly, bring attention more fully to the present in order to discover the richness of whats happening in relationship with others, and begin to see and co-explore aspects of yourself you may have been unaware of before in service of greater self-understanding, expression and awareness. You'll have the opportunity to learn and use new tools to participate in circles by sharing yourself, understanding others, and growing in both enjoyment of and capacity for presence and deep connection.

The more Ive seen people Circle the more genuine, " in the moment" conversations Ive seen become possible for them.

Likewise, the more Ive seen them become comfortable in their own skin, get clear on what their feeling, wanting or needing in any moment, grow in a sense of presence and natural interest in others, and generally embody a deep capacity for presence and authenticity.

If connecting profoundly with others, developing present moment awareness, and learning new communication skills inspires you, come try Circling out! The cost is $20

results.description:
There are new rules and <a>regulations</a> concerning the Tuesday <a>night</a> games. Please scroll down and read them all before signing up for the event.


There may not be space for you if you don't.


<a>Table</a> Top Role <a>Playing</a> Game Night!


This is the official <a>RPG game</a> night of the NY SciFi/Fan Meetup Group.

Every Tuesday night we get together to indulge in <a>Table Top RPGs</a>. There are <a>multiple games</a> going on at once, so getting involved in a game is <a>easy</a>.


For those of you unfamiliar with the term, a Table Top RPG (Role <a>Playing</a> Game) is a type of game where the players create characters based on the  story/system available and one person acts as a storyteller. Everyone interacts and works together to <a>create a story</a> and have a few laughs as well.


New Rules for Signing Up:


How to <a>sign up</a>: There will be at leas two <a>games running</a> each week.  You will be able to see who is running, what games are being <a>played</a>, and who is <a>playing</a> below. There will be a total of six spots <a>open</a> in each game, so if a game has filled up you will not be able to join that game. 


When you <a>sign up</a>, leave a comment stating which game you would like to participate in and your name will be added to the roster. If you would like to leave a game or switch over to another game in <a>progress</a>, simply speak to Justin or Cat. They will let you know if there is <a>open</a> space to do so.


If it is your first time <a>attending</a> a game, we have pre-made characters for you to <a>select</a> from. Beginning on your third RPG event, you may choose to make an original character for whatever game you're currently participating in.


Can I run my own game?: If you would like to run your own game, please contact Justin or Cat to reserve a slot.


Need Dice?: Please bring yours if you have some if you need extra I will provide some.

Current GMs

Justin

Cat


Steve

If you've heard of blockchain, it's probably been in the context of a bitcoin conversation. But the applications of blockchain technology extend far beyond the world of finance.

results.description:
We will begin our medley - a musical portrait of the types of the Enneagram - with a session on Type Eight, "The Challenger."  (Please see announcement for our September meeting for background on this series.)

For this selected Enneagram-type in particular, there should be plenty of colorful material with which we can work.  Besides having a style with a certain rather obvious personal dynamism, Eights seem historically to be over-represented as creators of music in a variety of genres.

As discussed at our planning-meeting, this is intended as an optionally-interactive series.  You are invited to bring and present your own example: a short piece of music (or two) that you feel exemplifies "Eightness" in its actual musical texture (i.e., not just in the lyrics, though these too can add to the overall effect).  Ideally, you will be able to find an example created by a composer you can confidently identify as a real-life Type Eight.  This way, we can explore some of the possibly subtle ways in which the creator's personality shows up in the music.  Please also bring some brief biographical information on the creator, especially if the person is not likely to be well-known by the rest of us.

If you'd rather just come and listen, that's also fine.  Please come at our usual meeting-time (7p) in this case.

For those who would like to play their musical examples for the group, please come promptly at 6:30.  We'll be fitting together the contributed pieces, and possibly making selections (if some people bring several), during the half-hour before the full meeting.  You are welcome to contact the Organizer (click on name or photo in column at left, then click "message") with any typing-issues or other questions or concerns.


If you didn't attend our planning meeting (9/8/15), you can still participate.  Please consider whether coming as listener, at least for the first session, makes the best sense for you.  If you're burning to contribute, we are still open, but please contact the Organizer at least a couple days prior to the meeting.  (No need to send a separate message if you're coming as a listener, but please do RSVP in advance.)

Looking forward to beginning this project -

Nicholas
results.name: Music Series (pt I) - Enn. Type 8

results.description:
Our Tuesday night Central Park training workouts are typically tempo runs or hill repeats.  These workouts are usually very well attended with a wide variety of paces.

The meeting spot is at the 72nd street transverse by Bethesda Fountain. There we'll give the full workout details, including distance, pacing groups, expected run time, and where we plan on meeting at the end. You can expect a typical workout to be between 5 and 8 miles (or less during hill workouts).

A note on warm ups: We do not do a full warm up as a group in Central Park, so we encourage you to show up at 7 p.m. having jogged an easy mile or two ahead of time. 


If it's your first time meeting us, feel free to come a few minutes early with any questions.  There are many other groups who meet on 72nd St so look for the one with folks in Whippet singlets.

Please note that there is no place to store bags inside Central Park. Pack light, or store your bags at a nearby gym if you are a member. Another option is the New York Running Company at the Time Warner Center, which stays open until 9pm: http://www.therunningcompany.net/new-yorks-homepage

results.description:
Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs. One game is 55-60 minutes. Be early. Every player rotates as a Goalie for 6 minutes, time it with an electronic scoreboard. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt, indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. 

No fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence. No charging, no displacing with your arms or body to gain the position on the ball. No running into the opponent. Play the ball, not the player. Time it, don’t foul it. 

Refunds: Cancel your RSVP 24 hours or more before the game and we will make the refund. No refund for late cancelations; no exceptions. 

Name of the school William J. O’Shea (100W): The school entrance is located on West 77th street between Columbus and Amsterdam avenues (pretty much in the middle of the block) on the south side of the street. You'll see a row of 5-6 metal doors. Open the door or ring the buzzer (on your right), Please wait and someone will open the door for you.  the court is on the second floor. 

For questions: Use the MEETUP message and notifications tools. 

Post pictures and videos at:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Futsalacrossamerica?ref=hl

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FutsalAcrossA

Thank you for being part of Futsal Across America.

Enjoy the game!

results.description:
Pump it up!  The Gym is definitely back!  Great session earlier where we did a nice improv warm-up and then delved into a lot of Commercial cold reads.  I know I got some real insight into some of the highest paid work we actors can get.  Not too shabby and thank you to my colleagues at the Gym for the insight!  Spotting for each other is what the Gym is all about.    

Now for some upgrades and updates.  I was inspired by a fellow gym rat to put together a little handout for all the new and old members.  Here is what I and my friend were thinking:  We put a synopsis of some of the major acting schools format together.  So far I have read books by and taken classes on Chekov, Hagen, Stanislavski, Barrow and Boleslavsky.  Condensing each of them into some main points would be helpful I think so let me know if you would want something like that.  Also given the egalitarian ethos of the Gym if you have anything you would like added feel free to sent it to me or bring it to the Gym and we can see about putting it in so it can help everyone!  

While I am hesitant to put a rigid format on our freedom at the Gym I think a little warm-up with improv and then choices of Prepared scenes, monologues and then cold reads of monologues or commercials seems to be going great!   Can you think of a place where you get all of that for only a studio split of 5$?  I didnt think so.   Come and put in the work or just get a little taste of the art and play with a supportive and insightful bunch!

Looking forward to seeing everyone, chatting about projects and doing a lot of Working Out of those Acting Chops!
results.name: Pump, pump the jam.

This meetup is held the first Tuesday of each month and has two purposes.

First, it serves as a general networking opportunity for Permies in the area to meet each other and to provide mutual aid. What are you working on and where? results.description:
This Month's book: Future Crimes: Everything Is Connected, Everyone Is Vulnerable and What We Can Do About It   by Marc Goodman

It won't surprise many people to read that computers, networks, and personal information are under constant attack. Most of us install a commonly available anti-virus program, mind our clicks, and hope for the best. More than that seems like work, and stories of data theft have become so ubiquitous that a certain amount of desensitization is probably inevitable. Well, Goodman's book should take care of that. When your C.V. includes titles like "futurist-in-residence with the FBI," you've seen who's creeping through those internet pipes, and it's harrowing; his litany of cyber criminals and their multitudinous misdeeds are often shocking in their inventiveness and audacity, and Goodman brings the nightmares one after another at an almost breathless pace. But not all is hopeless--Goodman aims to educate, offering from high-level policy to practical layman's advice for buttoning down your own data. Despite the scare factor, it's a fun, fast, and fascinating 400 pages. My only quibble is with the title, which implies a coming threat. The threat is here, and the future is now.



This event is hosted by Bob Braine. for information on this month's book, email [masked]. This event is FREE and OPEN TO THE PUBLIC.
results.name: Future Crimes:Everything Is Connected, Everyone Is Vulnerable and What We Can Do

Join us for a weekly get together of sometimes frank and hopefully always constructive criticism of your literary work. There is no restriction on the type of genre and only a few rules:

1. Bring up to 6 double spaced typed pages of your work for reading. Additional copies would be helpful in order to allow others in the group to follow along.

2. The author is not allowed to speak while feedback is being provided.

3. The same piece should not be reread at a future workshop.

We will meet every Tuesday at 7 PM on the first floor of the Central Library, unless a meetup is not scheduled for that date due to a holiday or other event. A floor plan link is available at http://www.brooklynpubliclibrary.org/sites/default/files/files/pdf/central/floorplan.pdf.

We rent space at the Edgar Cayce Center. Meeting cost is a nominal $5 to cover expenses.

This Tuesday meeting, our special guest via Skype from California will be teacher Hou Hee (Frank) Chan for the full hour. He will cover both the theory and practice of ZNQG.

Here is a link to his website

http://www.chilelwellness.com/chilel-qigong/

Drawing from over 40 years of training and practice in Taiji and Qìgōng and his background as an engineer, the hallmark of Chan Laoshi’s teaching is his ability to explain to his students HOW and WHY a movement is performed in terms that they are able to understand. Chan Laoshi's philosophy is that Qìgōng is not something that is mysterious. He defines Qìgōng as "exercise with mindfulness." Qìgōng is what we practice once we become aware of our body and aware of how we move our body.

results.description:
SJC's Monthly EAT, MEET, TALK Meetings take place on the first Tuesday evening of each month at City Hall at 7pm in Caucus Room #204.

Please RSVP at the Eventbrite link provided, so we get an accurate headcount and have enough food on hand for those joining us for the EAT part of the evening !

RSVP here https://www.eventbrite.com/e/sjc-monthly-meeting-eat-meet-talk-2015-tickets-15259846612

OCTOBER TOPIC - ALTERNATIVE TRANSPORTATION FOR JERSEY CITY !

As many of us consider alternatives to using automobiles, mobility options are a popular topic.  JC has been ranked very high amongst city surveys looking at sustainable public transportation systems, focusing on access to public transportation - PATH, Light Rail - and usage by folks who live and / or work here, HOWEVER, given the planned growth for the City, the need for additional options is a common conversation.  YES, Bike mobility has been invested in with the new Citi Bike Share program and deployment of many miles of bike lanes, but what about our BUS SYSTEM ? Tonight we'll talk about Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) opportunities and also get an update on what's happening with Biking in JC.

GUEST SPEAKERS -

MB 'Bon' Provenzano, collaborates with SJC and Vision42 in Manhattan, and is a volunteer for the National Association for Railroad Passengers. He enjoys urban trekking, cycling, and long rail journeys.  He is currently Project / Quality Manager for British Aerospace, working on control and communications systems for air traffic control towers; amongst other technical grad degrees he will complete a Masters in Sustainable Transportation from University of Washington this coming academic year.

Patrick Conlon, board member of Bike JC and insightful participant in the Occupy Wall Street movement, brings his perspectives on collective action, community collaboration and advocacy movements.  Patrick is co-creator with Kris Reis, VP of Bike JC, of the GHOST BIKE MEMORIAL http://www.jerseycityindependent.com/2015/06/jersey-city-to-make-ghost-bikes-permanent-memorials/

Bon Provenzano - This presentation will compare the advantages and disadvantages of modern light rail systems and bus rapid transit (BRT) systems.  It will then look at specific cases of Bogota and Medellin, Columbia, and how these systems have fit into overall objectives of urban movement, and how their lessons might or might not be relevant to Jersey City.  The presentation explores each system and concludes that the selection process between the two should be entirely route specific and explores the relationship between public transit, private cars, pedestrians and other modes.

Patrick Conlon - will update us on BikeJC.org and their new initiatives, and provide an update on the Citi Bike Share program and what's happening with the deployment of Bike Lanes in Jersey City and connecting networks for bikers.

———————————————————————————————————

If you are interested to join one of SJC's Working Groups, these monthly meetings are the place to jump in - this is a BIG agenda and more hands on deck are needed !

If you are interested in getting more involved please take our Welcome Survey - is very quick and will also put you into our system so you can receive all of our notifications.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

These EAT, MEET, TALK programs provide opportunity to network over delicious local fare, listen to relevant Community Org / Expert Presentations and be included in discussion about SJC Business / Project activities.  All are welcome and is a great way to plug-in to the sustainability movement in Jersey City.

Standing Agenda:

7pm - EAT and network with other like-minded folks interested in a greener, cleaner Jersey City.

7:30pm - MEET with JC Community Leaders, Municipal Officials and Field Professionals about VARIOUS Sustainability Topics important to Jersey City stakeholders; opportunity to get educated !

8:30pm - TALK with SJC Committee and Project Leaders for updates on our activities and learn how you can plug-in as a volunteer and / or gain our support for initiatives in your neighborhood..

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Please note our 2015 SJC Green Drinks +ART events will now be held quarterly – venues TBA, stay tuned !

<a href="http://sustainablejc.org/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/Culinary-Conf-Center-logo.gif"></a>

results.description:
The New York Review of Science Fiction Readings
presents
Matthew Kressel
Brooke Bolander
guest curator: Amy Goldschlager
Tuesday, October 6th -- doors open 6:30 p.m.
$7 suggested donation
The Commons Cafe | 388 Atlantic Avenue
(directions & links below)
Our 25th Anniversary Season continues with all participants being from the counties of Queens or Kings. Some may be recent transplants, but dat, er, that still scars one for life -- and for the better.

---
Brooke Bolander writes weird things of indeterminate genre, most of them leaning rather heavily towards fantasy. She attended the University of Leicester[masked] studying History and Archaeology and is an alum of the 2011 Clarion Writers’ Workshop at UCSD. Her work has been featured in Lightspeed, Strange Horizons Nightmare, Reflection’s Edge, and the upcoming anthologies Aliens: Recent Encounters and Help Fund My Robot Army. She is a clean-burning, energy-efficient engine that runs primarily off tea, the works of Peter S. Beagle and Fumito Ueda, and feedback from her readers. Follow her on Twitter @BBolander, or at her website, http://brookebolander.com/

--
Matthew Kressel is a multiple Nebula Award finalist and World Fantasy Award finalist. His first novel, King of Shards, debuts October 13th from Resurrection House. His fiction has or will soon appear in such markets as Clarkesworld, Lightspeed, Nightmare, io9.com, Beneath Ceaseless Skies, Interzone, Apex Magazine, and the anthologies After, Naked City, The People of the Book, Launch Pad, and many other markets. He was the former editor and publisher of the acclaimed 'zine Sybil's Garage and he published the World Fantasy Award-winning Paper Cities. Alongside veteran editor Ellen Datlow, he co-hosts the Fantastic Fiction at KGB reading series in Manhattan. He has been a member of the Altered Fluid writers group for more than a decade, studies the Yiddish language in his spare time, and is preternaturally obsessed with the film Blade Runner. If you ask politely, he might recite whole scenes from the film. Find him on Twitter as @mattkressel and his blog at http://matthewkressel.net/

--
Amy Goldschlager is an editor, proofreader, and book/audiobook reviewer. She has worked for several major publishers, and has also contributed reviews and features to the Los Angeles Review of Books, Locus, Kirkus, Publishers Weekly, ComicMix, and AudioFile magazine. She lives in Brooklyn and can be found virtually at http://amygoldschlager.com/

---
The New York Review of Science Fiction Reading Series provides performances from some of the best writers in science fiction, fantasy, speculative fiction, etc. The series usually takes place the first Tuesday of every month, but maintains flexibility in time and space, so be sure to stay in touch through the mailing list, the Web, and Facebook.

We will have free cheese and crackers on hand, and the Cafe will see to your other needs. The Jenna freebie table continues, as does the raffle for any who donate.

After the event, please join us as we treat our readers for dinner and drinks at the cafe, with its evolving menu.

--
Jim Freund is Producer and Executive Curator of The New York Review of Science Fiction Readings. He has been involved in producing radio programs of and about literary sf/f since 1967. His long-running live radio program, “Hour of the Wolf,” broadcasts and streams every Wednesday night/Thursday morning from 1:30-3:00 AM. Programs are available by stream for 2 months after broadcast. (Check http://hourwolf.com/, or join the Hour of the Wolf group on Facebook for details.) In addition, Jim is Podcast Host and Post-Production Editor for the twice-consecutive Hugo Award-winning Lightspeed Magazinee.

The Brooklyn Commons Cafe at 388 Atlantic Avenue is an open and collaborative movement building space, only minutes away from the Hoyt-Schermerhorn and Atlantic Avenue subway stops in downtown Brooklyn. The Commons provides resources to the progressive community including affordable office and meeting spaces as well as an event venue that can host anything from parties and benefits to forums, performances, films and workshops. results.description:
A Course in Miracles Healing Clinic at CRS
 Mon. & Tue. 7 – 7:40 pm
Sun 1 – 2 pm (12 – 1 pm on 2nd Sun of the month)
Suggested donation $20. No one is turned away.

Bring any issue you are facing right now — physically, emotionally, mentally, and/or spiritually. With eyes closed (you will be seated and a healer will stand nearby; no touching is involved), a CRS healer, trained in A Course in Miracles and spiritual reading/healing, will observe you with his inner sight, free of any judgments, as your truly are, a perfect shining spirit. Together, will ask the Holy Spirit (or Inner Guide if you prefer) to bring us directly to whatever seed thought is causing your current issues and ask for guidance about how your spirit really wants to make use of your present situation for its growth and sharing of love. After about 10 minutes of meditation, we will share the inspirational guidance that we receive. 

Aside from sharing the message that we receive from the Holy Spirit, we don't talk during this meetup event. We share healing quietly and provide you with an opportunity to come to rest, reflect, and remember who you truly are, in a supportive, non-judgmental, meditative environment.

We'd like to offer you an opportunity to experience stillness of mind and peace so that you can return to harmony with your true nature and purpose. Then you will find that rather than needing "solutions" to "problems" you will realize that you have no problems except those that you project.

We call this spiritual healing but it is not religious nor connected with any church or group. It is simply a practice of meditating together on our true nature and connecting with universal spirit/energy or what you will.

A Note About the Role of Words in Healing: "Strictly speaking, words play no part at all in healing. The motivating factor is prayer, or asking. What you ask for you receive. But this refers to the prayer of the heart, not to the words you use in praying. Sometimes the words and the prayer are contradictory; sometimes they agree. It does not matter. God does not understand words, for they were made by separated minds to keep them in the illusion of separation. Words can be helpful, particularly for the beginner, in helping concentration and facilitating the exclusion, or at least the control, of extraneous thoughts. Let us not forget, however, that words are but symbols of symbols. They are thus twice removed from reality...." — A Course in Miracles Manual for Teachers, Section 21

"Since only the mind can be sick, only the mind can be healed. Only the mind is in need of healing." —"PSYCHOTHERAPY: Purpose, Process and Practice,"Supplements to A Course in Miracles
results.how_to_find_us: CRS is located one block east of Broadway and one and a half blocks south of Union Square, above Think Coffee shop.

results.description:
Prospect Park, is a sprawling green oasis tucked inside one of the most popular neighborhoods in Brooklyn. But did you know, it’s also been the scene of at least 4 murders over the years, and is home to a Quaker Cemetery?


Well, we know all about it, and now you will too. So join us, for the second meeting of the Brooklyn Paranormal Society on October 6th, 2015 while we drink wine from a bag, and reach out to the spirits that inhabit* Prospect Park.

* Hopefully.

About The Murders:

We will attempt to visit as many of the sites below as possible over the course of the nights investigation. Below are some articles related to the murders, and the sites we will be visiting.

Adult male, shot: http://www.nytimes.com/1994/05/26/nyregion/maximum-term-imposed-in-killing-over-bike.html

Adult male, stabbed: http://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/24/nyregion/24stabbing.html

Adult male, beaten: http://www.nydailynews.com/news/crime/prospect-park-slay-victim-identified-article-1.317478

Adult male, shot: http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/25/nyregion/25ems.html


Adult female, strangled*: http://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/14/nyregion/police-doubtful-of-single-killer-in-5-stranglings.html


* Body was dumped in park.

Prospect Park Map:

https://www.prospectpark.org/visit-the-park/park-map/
results.how_to_find_us: Anthony will be wearing a Goosebumps hat. Text (718) 513-9807 if you will be late, or need directions.
results.name: BKPS Investigates: Prospect Park

results.description:
October's Smutty Book will be This Man by Jodi Ellen Malpas.  Recommended by Becky, and seconded (sort of) by Gerda. Survey says it will be hot, but share the familiar inexperienced woman meets powerful man structure we've seen a lot.  Gerda reluctantly says she can't put it down, so that's saying something.  

From the Publisher: 

Young interior designer Ava O’Shea has an appointment for a first consultation at The Manor with the owner, Mr Jesse Ward. She is expecting nothing more than an overweight, cravat wearing, well-to-do countryman, and on arrival, nothing would suggest otherwise. How wrong could she be? This Man is devastatingly handsome, charming and confident. He is also a conceited, hedonistic playboy, who knows no boundaries. Ava desperately does not want to be attracted to him, but she can’t control the overwhelming effect he has on her. Every instinct is telling her to run, so she does, but Jesse Ward is not so willing to let her go. He wants her and is determined to have her. She knows she is heading for heartbreak, but how can she run when he won’t let her?

From Goodreads:  

Loved It: 

Jenny Levine:MOVE OVER 50 SHADES OF GREY TRILOGY AND CROSSFIRE SERIES...

THERE'S A NEW STEAMY TRILOGY IN TOWN! 
I'm adding "This Man" to my list of favorites. I still love FSoG and The Crossfire Series though. HA.


Indifferent: 
Aestas Book Blog: I'm torn on how to rate this book. I liked some of it, I disliked some of it, some of it was thrilling, some of it was frustrating so...


Hated It:  


Navessa: Things you would probably enjoy more than reading this piece of shiterature:
- Letting Hannibal Lecter give you your yearly pap smear.
- Euthanizing your favorite pet.
- Allowing your best friend to run over your foot with their car.
- Contracting MRSA.
- Watching every single episode of Guiding Light.

results.name: October Smutty Book Club - This Man by Jodi Ellen Malpas

results.description:
Open Office Hours

Meeting every Tuesday evening, 7:00PM - 10:00PM

This month's host: Codesters (codesters.com) 

Check out their blog! http://blog.codesters.com/ 

---

Office hours is open to developers of any background and skill level. Newcomers to programming, Python, or NYC are all welcome, as well as experienced programmers and locals. The purpose of this event is to promote learning and community involvement within the NYC Python community.

Activities vary and may include (but are not limited to):

Informal tech talks: Topics can be anything related to Python or programming. Have a topic you'd like to see presented? Leave a comment starting with "Talk topic suggestion". Want to present? Message the organizers.

Technical discussions: Bring your code and / or questions about any relevant topic, and there will most likely be someone present who can help. For questions about a specific topic, please leave a comment in the form of "Need help with Django / Nginx / SQL". If you're able to help with a particular topic, please leave a comment in the form of "Can help with Flask / Apache / NoSQL".

Note: Recruiting and other solicitation are not allowed at these events. These are run for developers by developers. Behavior that makes others uncomfortable will not be tolerated, and offenders will be asked to leave.

Profuse thanks go to our sponsors for loaning us this space and providing refreshments.

Thank you, and see you Tuesday night!

results.description:
Come out Tuesday night to learn more about Sailing in the Grenadines next February 2016 with Sailors NYC!


Sailors NYC is a fun Sailing Club located in Tribeca on Pier 25. Learn to Sail with ASA Certification Classes! or Sail in the Hudson on 30' Sailboats as a Captain or Crew ~


Sailors NYC sailed in St. Martin & St. Barths (in 2014) and the US and Spanish VI (in 2015). In 2016 we are planning to take the Grenadines - and we hope to have YOU on board with us!  February 20-28, 2016.

This year we are offering a WOMEN ONLY boat as well as an ASA instruction boat - where participants will be able to take any of ASA 101, 103 and 104 courses. We are looking to make this the biggest Sailing Vacation we had so far and to include at least 3 boats and have 25-30 people on board! Do not miss this experience!

We invite you to join us for a presentation of the 2016 Grenadines Vacation where you'll be able to meet members who joined our previous flotillas as well as meet up with some other sailing enthusiasts. Check out more of the initial information on our website.

 24 Ave C, New York, NY 10009

Rum Tasting, Music and Presentation of 2016 Sailing Vacation Flotilla in the Grenadines - February 20-28, 2016

results.description:
Dads,

Tony Shalhoub is hosting a screening Tuesday night 10/6 at 7p in NYC at the Sunshine.  The theme is the role fathers play in their daughters education.  

We're invited to see the new documentary about Malala Yousafzai, the youngest Nobel Peace Prize recipient, at an advance screening of HE NAMED ME MALALA at the Sunshine on October 6th at 7PM.

Much of Malala's story revolves around her strong bond with her father, and this is a great bonding opportunity for those of you with older kids to discuss her story.  You are welcome to bring a guest or come alone for a Dads Night Out.  Please make sure all attendees are at least 13 years of age or older.

The movie is rated PG-13 for thematic elements.

********** 
NOTE: In order to attend you MUST register at this link for a screening pass

**********

We currently have the limit set to 25 attendees.  If we reach the limit and more would like to attend, please join the waitlist.  I can reach out to them and try to request more tickets!

Trailer

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cug1-eTOVSk

Synopsis

Targeted by the Taliban and severely wounded by a gunshot when returning home on her school bus in Pakistan’s Swat Valley, the then 15-year-old (she turned 18 this July) was singled out, along with her father, for advocating for girls’ education. The attack sparked an outcry from supporters around the world. She miraculously survived and is now a leading campaigner for girls’ education globally as co-founder of the Malala Fund.

Acclaimed documentary filmmaker Davis Guggenheim (An Inconvenient Truth, Waiting for Superman) shows us how Malala, her father Zia and her family are committed to fighting for education for all girls worldwide. The film gives us an inside glimpse into this extraordinary young girl’s life – from her close relationship with her father who inspired her love for education, to her impassioned speeches at the UN, to her everyday life with her parents and brothers.
