results.description:
If you are looking for a great place to get after work cocktails Ten Bells on the Lower East Side may be the perfect spot. Here are some of the reasons you will love this place.

While they have a full bar, they have a great wine selection as well. Some of them are excellent and are only $6 during happy hour. They also have a great food menu with Oysters being only $1 during happy hour. 

This is a great place to catch up with friends and after you check it out you will definitely be back for date night. Here are a couple of reviews to give you an idea of the ambiance. 

Stopped in for a glass wine after dinner at a nearby spot. The space is amazing and the it a had a really sexy vibe. I felt like I was in a quaint Spanish town in the countryside. Great place for a date or just to hang out with a group of friends.

One of my fav NYC spots. Amazingly charming atmosphere, wonderful selection of wines, and delicious small bites to eat. The ambiance is typical LES and very charming.

I hope to see you there. 

Ten Bells

247 Broome St, New York 10002

(Btwn Orchard & Ludlow St)

 (212)[masked]

tenbellsnyc.com
results.name: Hump Day Happy Hour in Manhattan

results.description:
Come join us for a night of board gaming fun. We play all sorts of board games and card games. We tend to play more euro games so please keep that in mind. Bringing a game is not necessary, but if you have one you want to play bring it along.

Valley Stream train station is very close about three blocks.

For those who drive:

• Street parking meters are until 6pm. If you come early, W. Jamaica Ave has a free parking lot, behind the pizzeria.


We have permission from the restaurant owner to play in the restaurant on the condition that everyone consumes something. At least a soda. The restaurant also has a bakery attached with treats.

We play in the restaurant; to get there, you enter the bakery walk to the back, then make a right. There you'll find the restaurant, we are located by the front windows.

• The bakery is located across the street from Mitchell's restaurant. There is a lighted OPEN sign on the window.

• Be aware this group has an age limit, those who come to game must be adults under 40**

**Due to popular demand we will now be having a 3 no show rule. If you RSVP but can't make it please take the time to take yourself off. Our group is small and we do plan our games on how many members will be showing up. Even if you unrsvp right before we start, one of us is always checking and we appreciate the info. I'll send you a warning after the 2nd no show, but after the third I'll have to take you out of our group.
results.how_to_find_us: We will be located inside the restaurant section by the windows

results.description: Alexander's physical body was dead, but to many of his subjects he had just joined the immortal gods. For those mortals left who had accompanied Alexander on his conquests there was one overriding worldly concern: who shall succeed him? His Bactrian bride Roxana was pregnant. But would it be a boy or a girl? Alexander's campaigns had produced a plethora of ambitious men suitable for commanding armies: Perdiccas, Craterus, Leonatus, Lysimachus, Ptolomy, Eumenes, Antigonus Monophthalmus ensconced in Asia Minor and Antipater besieged by revolting Greeks in Lamia. Who among them would be the strongest?
results.name: Game of Thrones: The Wars of the The Diadochi

results.description:
SciCafe: Seeing Inside Bats

Join Curator Nancy Simmons and postdoctoral fellow Abigail Curtis, from the Museum’s Department of Mammalogy, for an exciting journey inside the world (and bodies!) of bats. Often small in size and difficult to study, these amazing mammals are known for many remarkable qualities including powered flight, echolocation, and diverse feeding strategies. Using CT-scanning technology, Simmons and Curtis are taking a new look at bat skeletons from their wrists to their sinuses.

About the speakers:
Dr. Nancy Simmons is the Curator-in-charge of the Department of Mammalogy and Professor in the Richard Guilder Graduate School at the American Museum of Natural History. Her research focuses on the evolution of bats — the only flying mammals — and includes everything from fieldwork with living bats to studies of 52 million year old fossil bats (the oldest known). She was also part of the team that helped to build the Tree of Life for Mammals.
Dr. Abigail Curtis is a Gerstner Scholar Postdocotral Research Fellow working with Dr. Nancy Simmons in the Department of Mammalogy at the American Museum of Natural History. She is interested in understanding patterns in the evolution of mammal skulls. Her research focuses specifically on the complex and poorly understood internal anatomy of mammal skulls. Curtis has worked on taxa including the carnivores (bears, wolves, lions, and kin) and, most recently, bats in order to understand more about how diversity in skull morphology evolves, and how it relates to diet, ecology, and behavior.
results.name: Bats

results.description:
We talked about reading the book "Causality" by Judea Pearl as our next long-term reading project! There are a LOT of pre-requisites, and I want to spend a little time to make sure everyone starts off strong!

If you can, skim over a little of "Causality" (even if just the table of contents). You can find the first edition here, but we'd cover the 2nd edition in the group:
http://bayes.cs.ucla.edu/BOOK-99/book-toc.html

Please leave requests for pre-requisites to cover in the comments! I've added a few to start us off -- please add more!  If you support a request, "Like" a person's request so I'll know what subjects to prioritize. I'll update this page description with an outline and a date once we've figured out what to cover!

Update (10/1/2015):

Looks like there was some interest in all the pre-reqs listed! 

 We'll prioritize some basic probability manipulations, and then move into the basics of Bayesian Networks.  We'll stay in the weeds pretty much the whole time by stating properties/theorems and doing example calculations.  

We'll touch on intuition for some of the trickier concepts (e.g. conditional independence), but won't focus too much time on it as an end in itself.

Logistical Notes:

• Be sure to be on time!  If you're more than 15 minutes late, you won't be able to get in.  

• The receptionist may be not downstairs with the guest list promptly at 6:00.  If you arrive and the security desk is unaware of the meetup, just hang out until she arrives downstairs to check you in!

• Be sure to bring ID for security! 

• There will be signs upstairs ("Math Meetup") directing you to the room.
results.name: Pre-requisites for "Causality" (1/2)

results.description:
WHAT WE DO

Open space for artists & technologists to get hands-on with new technology. We supply a bunch of hardware and a chill environment so you can hack away.

Tweet: @hardwarehacklab at #ThoughtWorksNYC

Visit: hardwarehacklab.io

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0kxNCYpxcXM

We use creative coding environments like openFrameworks or Max/MSP to play with everything from webcams to Oculus Rift. People of all experience levels, from beginners to veterans are welcome here.

WARNING

This meetup has no particular structure. We don't have 'hack lab' projects. We work on whatever we, and you, bring in each week - which could be anything.

The schedule is loose, the feeling is social and non-judgemental. We are just curious and want to see your projects. So bring what you have and share!

ROSTER

Oculus, Kinect 1/2, Arduino, Leap, Glass, Depth video, Brain-Computer Interface, openFrameworks, SuperCollider, Max/MSP, vvvv, Processing.

DO YOU HAVE SPECIFIC NEEDS?

Some of these items are only available on request or particular occasions. Use the comments below and direct messages to find out if particular hardware or people with particular skills will be around that week.

If you can't confirm, still drop by and meet us. The lab is a great place to come and learn and meet people.
results.name: Hardware Hack Lab

results.description:
The Beginner Buddhist Book Circle is for anyone interested in or new to Buddhism. In this biweekly series, we’ll explore classic introductory Buddhist books. Although we have “reading assignments”, the meetings focus more on basic Buddhist teachings rather than strict discussions of the books. Our meetings are casual and informal; all levels of interest and experience are welcome. When possible, we’ll have copies of the current book available at no cost. Meetings occur on the second Wednesday and fourth Thursday of the month unless otherwise noted. Please see the Meetup page and calendar for the full schedule.

*** Right Now We’re Reading: “The Heart of the Buddha's Teachings" by Thich Nhat Hanh***

In "The Heart of the Buddha's Teachings", renowned Vietnamese Buddhist monk, teacher, poet, and peace activist Thich Nhat Hanh (Thay) presents the essentials of Buddhist teachings in a clear, compassionate, and concise manner. In addition to covering teachings at the core of all Buddhist traditions, Thay also covers many key Mahayana Buddhist teachings. In all discussions, Thay helps guide us to the heart of what the Buddha taught; the transformation of suffering into peace, joy, and liberation.

First released in 1999, "The Heart of the Buddha's Teachings" has become a classic and essential read for anyone interested in learning more about basic Buddhist teachings. The book is widely available in bookstores and libraries in print, ebook form, and audio book form.

For the Oct. 7th meeting, please read through Chapters 2 through 4. Discussion points include:

-What did the Buddha first teach?


-What are the Four Noble Truths?


-What are some useful ways to approach Buddhist teachings?


***

Happy reading and we hope to see you soon!
results.name: Beginner Buddhist Book Circle

In this meetup, Jay Garcia and Stan Bershadskiy will present on React Native for iOS and Android.  They will discuss key features of this new and exciting library and do deep dives on how all of the pieces fit together.  Key demonstrations will be provided for applications that tailor to both platforms.  Stan and Jay will answer the question in the industry's collective minds: "Did Facebook make all mobile HTML5 frameworks irrelevant?"


We're moving to a new venue this time in the financial district area. The space is going to be a more intimate environment allowing you to ask more questions and really dive into the material. 

Because of the limited space, we have to cap the meetup attendee limit. We would really appreciate it if you only RSVP yes if you're certain you will attend. If do RSVP and something comes up that you can not attend please change your status ASAP.

results.description:
Not all incentives are created equal. 

In 2000, Uri Gneezy's research team found that charging parents fines for picking up their kids late from a daycare actually increased the number of late pickups, as people saw it as a fee for service rather than a punishment. 

Since then, research in behavioral economics has shown that small differences in the framing and structure of incentives programs can greatly impact effectiveness. Yet despite the millions of dollars organizations spend on incentive schemes, too little attention is paid to actually making them work. 

No matter what business you’re in, you likely spend most of your day trying to change behavior. Learn from a leading expert in behavioral economics and incentive design how insights from behavioral economics and psychology can be used to evaluate and improve incentive schemes.

Speakers: Uri Gneezy and Katie Baca-Motes


Uri’s early work on when and why incentives can backfire has become the cornerstone in a compelling line of research that explores when traditional economic theories fail to explain real human behavior. He is the co-author of the bestseller The Why Axis, and his work has been covered by the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, and has been featured in the bestselling books Freakonomics, Predictably Irrational, and Drive. His research focuses on putting behavioral economics to work in the real world, where theory can meet application. He is the Epstein/Atkinson Endowed Chair in Behavioral Economics and Professor of Economics & Strategy at the Rady School of Management, University of California, San Diego. 

Katie is the Managing Director of Gneezy Consulting where she helps organizations put behavioral economics to work. Before joining Gneezy Consulting, she led several large scale consumer behavior projects at The Walt Disney Company. Katie's research has been published in in the Journal of Consumer Research and her writing has been published on Time.com. She has an MBA from The Rady School of Management, UCSD.


Agenda

6:30 PM — Drinks, snacks, and socializing.

7–8 PM — Incentives Framework: Discussion with Uri and Katie (active participation and questions from the audience are encouraged so feel free to share your consumer behavior-related challenges!)

8 PM — Community announcements and more time to socialize
results.how_to_find_us: To get in, show your ID to the person at the front desk and tell them you're going to ideas42\/Floor 30.
results.name: When and Why Incentives (Don't) Work with Uri Gneezy & Katie Baca-Motes

results.description: Come hang out and watch puppies play - what could be better? Socialization is THE most important thing you can do for your puppy. It will help him or her learn valuable social skills and to not be afraid of novel or potentially scary things he or she will have to encounter on a daily basis. Often, people think their puppies are fine because they seem to love everything already, and when problems occur later down the line, it's a much bigger issue than it would have been if addressed in puppyhood. Take a professional's advice... make sure you socialize your puppy! Zen Dog Training Owner and Behavior Consultant Alexis Toriello supervises all play dates, answers training and behavior questions, and discusses topics like proper socialization and appropriate play.

results.description:
Join fellow technologists, entrepreneurs, and investors for the NY Enterprise Technology Meetup's (NYETM) October meetup on Wednesday 10/7/15 from 6:30pm-9:00pm!

For our October meetup we have some exciting companies demoing their technologies, including: 


• Pathgather - Pathgather is a new approach to enterprise learning that puts employees in control. They actually motivate individuals to learn and connect around professional development, so companies end up with a smarter, more effective workforce.


• Treadmill - A leading global investment bank has decided to commercialize one of its technology products and take venture funding to grow. They are now seeking to build an initial team and are looking for strong co-founders. The initial founders and architects of the product, called Treadmill, will share an overview of the technology and the go to market strategy.  Treadmill is a comprehensive enterprise-first application container technology, built to run over 4000 commercial and proprietary applications running today. Treadmill aggregates unused data center capacity into a usable general purpose compute fabric while solving complex enterprise problems associated with administration at scale, distribution, security and operations


• Ensilo - enSilo offers a real-time targeted attack exfiltration prevention platform. The company was founded on the recognition that targeted attacks are similar to chronic diseases where organizations that have made responsible and sustained investments in attack detection continue to be compromised. In the same way chronically-ill patients are provided a treatment to control the disease and increase longevity, organizations must deal in real time with a persistently compromised network. To that effect, enSilo prevents the consequences of an advanced targeted attack, namely, the theft of valuable data. The company is headed by security veterans from leading private and public sector companies, including Imperva, Akamai, and EMC. 


Sign up today, and if you have any questions, please contact Jon Lehr at [masked]. 

Looking forward to seeing you all soon!

Yours in collaboration, 
Jon  
www.nyetm.com

results.description:
Promoting Veganism in NYC - Union Square Park - SW corner of the park at E. 14th St. & Union Square W.  Look for the "Veg Meetup" sign. (This event also celebrates World Vegetarian Day - October 1st, World Day for Farmed Animals - October 2nd, and Vegetarian Awareness Month, which is the month of October. Vegan activist groups typically organize an activism event near the beginning of October to celebrate the day and persuade people to go vegan.)


Our meetup group has historically been a social group. (With the subtle activist mission of promoting veganism by showing people how much fun it can be.) In recent years we've done an occasional event that was directly an activist event, but these have been few and far between.

While we are, and will continue to be, mostly a social group, we'd like to step up the number of activist events we do.


This October 7th event will be outreach to the general public to promote and encourage a vegan diet & lifestyle. We will hand out literature in a welcoming manner so our audience will be open to seeing how great the benefits of veganism are for people, the non-human animals who share our world, and the planet itself.


We will meet at the designated location in Union Square at 6:30 pm (please arrive on time!). After a brief discussion on strategy and positioning of people, along with a few reminders for the group, we'll leaflet from 6:45 pm to 7:45 pm. Then our group will reassemble at the designated location and walk over to a nearby, all-vegan restaurant to have dinner, discuss our experiences and thoughts, and socialize.

We know that not everyone in our group is vegan, but on this day we will be promoting veganism. You are very welcome to join us even if you are not yet 100% vegan, but please understand that the literature we will hand out will promote a purely vegan lifestyle. Mostly on this day you will be handing out literature rather than talking to people, but if you do happen to speak with people, we are promoting a vegan diet and lifestyle for their tremendous benefits.

Where to meet: We will be meeting at the extreme southwest corner of Union Square Park, where Union Square West meets East 14th Street. We'll meet on the actual park block, right on the corner. You will see us holding a "VEG MEETUP" sign. We will meet right at 6:30pm. You may want to plan on being there early in order to be on time. Don't be late! We will talk for 15 minutes and then disburse to various nearby locations in the park.


We believe that grass-roots activism is vital in advancing the ideal, practice, and potential normalization of veganism in our world. So let's come together and do this, and also have fun while doing it!


Thank You All

Saurabh Dalal and David Greene
results.how_to_find_us: How to find us: We will be meeting at the extreme southwest corner of Union Square Park, where Union Square West meets East 14th Street. We'll meet on the actual park block, right on the corner. You will see us holding a "VEG MEETUP" sign.

results.description:
About tonight's show:

When we go online, we present a digital version of ourselves.

How do we transform when we interact inside our screens?

In this episode, TED speakers explore the expanding role of our "second selves."


Tonight's show features 5 TEDtalks:

• Jon Ronson: How Can Our Real Lives Be Ruined By Our Digital Ones?

• Philip Rosedale: Why Build A Virtual World?

• Adam Ostrow: After You Die, What Happens To The Digital You?


• Abha Dawesar: How Do Our Screens Distort Our Sense of Time?

Approximate timeline for the night:


7pm - Arrival & mingling

7:15pm - Show starts

8:15pm - Show ends; Short moderated discussion breaking out into smaller discussion groups.



Directions  & Parking:

The coffee house we've graciously been offered as a venue is located inside the Union Train station, near Kean University. It's in an unmarked building, so it might be tough to spot from a distance. To help you find it, here's what it looks like from down the street.

In addition, here is an overhead map to help you get your bearings and familiarize yourself with the area.

If you're driving to the event, you can park in any open spot at no charge. At this hour, there is no parking enforcement.

If you are taking the train, the venue is right inside the Union Train station, which is on the Raritan Valley Line. Here's an NJ Transit Map of the rail system to help you figure out if taking the train would be convenient for you.


To Find Us:

Rock'n' Joe is a cozy place. You'll see us gathered around the big pulldown movie screen on your left as soon as you walk in the front door. Grab a beverage or something to eat and come sit with us!

Please support the venue, Rock'n' Joe with a food or drink purchase (their coffee is sooo good!) so they can continue to welcome us back month after month!
results.how_to_find_us: The venue "Rock'n' Joe" is INSIDE the Union train station. If you have trouble finding it, please call Rock'n' Joe at 908-354-0660.

results.description:
Join other writers for an hour of focused writing!

6-7 pm - Show up early, stake out a spot and either socialize or get a jump on writing.
7:00 - Start. Introductions, and we'll share what we're working on
7:05 - Get down to business. An hour of silence and solid writing!
8:05- Brief follow up. People are encouraged to share experiences & ideas, network or take off as they like. Feel free to keep writing if you've got the momentum going!

If you're spending too much time THINKING about writing, come and join us for a session of focused writing. It may just be "pipe-cleaning" for now, but you'll feel better showing up at the page. No one will see what you've written or give you unsolicited advice.

WHERE: David Rubenstein Atrium, 62nd and Broadway.

SOME TIPS:

Please, come on time! If you come late, we will have already started.
Bring headphones if you don't want outside noise distraction.

Please RSVP only if you can make it, and update as soon as possible if your plans change. We have had far too many no-shows.

You will see progress in your writing project by spending the minimum of a single hour per week on it. This is your practice/focus time, so I hope to see you there.
results.name: NYC Shut Up & Write Meetup! - Columbus Circle

results.description:
Samaritans Safe Place meetings are free and offered twice a month at easily accessible locations in New York City.

Only survivors–those who have directly lost a loved one to suicide–can attend these meetings and participants must be 18 or older. There are no exceptions.

Meetings are run by trained facilitators that are, also, respected Samaritans volunteers who are experienced in dealing with the complex issues surrounding suicide and its aftermath. The meetings are run as peer support groups, where the people participating have the opportunity to focus on their thoughts and feelings, challenges and difficulties coping with their loss, without any undo pressures or expectations or other people judging them or giving them advice.

For more information: http://samaritansnyc.org/coping-with-suicide-loss/
results.name: Safe Place Suicide Survivor Support Group

results.description:
Join us for an open-format discussion of effective altruism topics! One suggested topic: given the increased emphasis recently from 80,000 Hours on how effective altruists in general should be contributing to "meta" work, what projects might some of us work on that could contribute to our understanding of effectiveness and impact in aid work, advocacy, risk reduction, et cetera? I'll have some preliminary ideas about projects based around working with open data sources.

(Also, If you're interested in developing and discussing project ideas but can't make it to the meeting, consider checking out the dot impact slack forum!)

***

For newcomers, read on:

If you aren't already familiar with the wider EA movement, I'm glad to have reached your eyeballs! Effective altruism is about recognizing the importance of using our lives to do the most good we can and looking for ways to help others that are high-impact and well-supported by evidence. This approach may sound obvious, but careful consideration of the impact of different strategies for doing good can lead to some surprising, and even controversial, conclusions. Ethical philosophy, career strategies, economics, and persuasion methods play important roles in these considerations, so EA attracts smart people and provides intellectually invigorating topics of discussion.

A great way to start learning about our perspective is to watch Peter Singer's TED talk: 
http://www.ted.com/talks/peter_singer_the_why_and_how_of_effective_altruism?language=en

If it piques your interest, have a look through the introductory links on the Effective Altruism Forum, or read Will MacAskill's excellent book on the topic, Doing Good Better -- and let us know what you think!

Feel free to send me a message if you'd like to know more. Hope to see you there!

-Chris
results.name: Effective Altruism discussion in Kips Bay

results.description:
COME CHECK IT OUT FOR ONLY $5 BUCKS!

Meditative Writing with Jessica Hinds

“It took me four years to paint like Raphael, but a lifetime to paint like a child.” – Pablo Picasso

There was a time when creativity was easy—when you were a child, driven by an endless desire to create, and no fear, no judgment, and no internal censor whatsoever.

The goal of meditative writing is to return you to that time, when finding your voice as a writer was as easy as being yourself, and raw creativity flowed as effortlessly as inspiration.

You’ll learn to banish writer’s block forever, find inspiration in an instant, and discover the heart of your story and your characters, by tapping into your own voice as a writer, and your deepest creative instincts.

How Does It Work?

Each session begins with a short guided meditation, followed by a series of carefully crafted meditative writing exercises, designed to transport you out of your everyday life, and connect you to the emotional truth of your story and of your characters.

Over 5 weeks, you’ll build a writing practice that allows you to get your pages flowing at will, recover the joy you’ve always felt with writing, and write from your most connected place every time you sit down with your characters.

Meetup Members can check out the first session for only $5 bucks with no obligation, to decide if the class is right for you!

Who Should Take Meditative Writing?


Whether you are brand new to writing, or a seasoned writer looking to inject energy back into your writing, meditative writing will change your writing life forever.

Designed for writers of all types, including screenwriters, playwrights, poets, novelists, and writers of any other genre, here are just a few of the many benefits of this approach:

Uncovering the Real Emotional Underbelly That Drives Great Films

Discovering Your True Voice

Creating More Provocative Dialogue, Images and Action

Developing an “Inspiration on Command” Writing Schedule

Injecting Joy Into Your Writing Process

Getting in Touch With Your Characters

Finding the Heart of Your Story

Discovering Theme

Natural Subtext

Opening Up Your Creative Side

Learning How To Write Even When You Can’t Find a “Quiet Place”

Connecting Yourself To Your Characters and Story Even If You Are Working On Assignment

Writing Cooler, Bigger, More Intense and Compelling Scenes

Learning To Love Your Weirdness and Understand Its Value

Relaxation

Confidence

Focus

Banishing Writers Block Forever

Fun!

Learn more.

----

NORMAL COST: $350

MEETUP MEMBERS:  Check out the first day of this  5-week workshop for only $5 bucks with no obligation!

Class Size is Strictly Limited To Allow All Students The Opportunity to Workshop And Receive Feedback On Their Writing. You MUST RSVP to attend this event.

PLEASE PLAN TO ARRIVE 5 MINUTES EARLY TO ASSURE THAT YOU DO NOT DISTURB THE MEDITATION.

You'll LOVE this workshop or your money back!
results.how_to_find_us: Take the elevator to the eighth floor and enter the door on your right!
results.name: Meditative Writing with Jessica Hinds

results.description:
We are eager to meet other New Yorkers that are looking for community in Christ and we hope you become a part of our family! Join us, Christ Fellowship, as we explore "The God I Never Knew". 

This is a 7 week series, taught by Pastor Robert Morris. In this series, we are going to be learning and talking about the Holy Spirit. 

Here's the breakdown of what to expect: 

Arrive at 2 W. 64th Street at 7pm. If you are just coming from work, we welcome you to bring your dinner. (No, you won't have to share ;) 

Once you arrive, you will find three or four small round tables. Grab your seat and get to know the people around you. 

At each table there will be a "table leader": Stephanie, Caroline, Danny, Pete, or Danielle. They are probably the nicest people I know, so you're in good hands!

Once life group starts, we will watch a 20 minute sermon video by Pastor Morris. After the video, each table will get to know each other and talk about that week's teaching.

We are so excited to meet you!! See you Wednesday :)

** Disclaimer:  this is a 7 week reoccurring MeetUp, however because we want to foster comfort and family, we will only be posting this MeetUp on the calendar for week 1. We hope to see you for every Wednesday life group though!
results.how_to_find_us: We rent out space in the NYSEC, you can find us in the lower level of the building. (Right side of the building, down the stairs)
results.name: Bible Study: The God I Never Knew

results.description:
Have you ever tried Salsa? How about CUBAN salsa? Now is your chance to learn this exciting and fun dance! On Wednesday, October 7th, we are offering a Cuban-style Salsa TOTAL BEGINNER introduction class! The class will start its curriculum from scratch, will be in a dance studio, and will be kept comfortably small to facilitate learning, so IT DOESN’T MATTER IF YOU HAVE NEVER DANCED! Also, having a partner is not required as we constantly rotate during the class. This format gives you the opportunity to practice your steps with various partners and prepares you for the social dance scene in a safe and pressure-free environment!

The teachers, a male and female, teach progressive levels of Cuban Salsa Partner work, also known as Casino and Rueda de Casino - an interactive group dance where there are constant partner exchanges with fun patterns executed in unison!

The October session of Cuban Salsa:

Wednesdays (September 30th - October 21st):

7:00-8:30pm Beginner Cuban Salsa & Rueda de Casino  - Level 1

This class is for absolute beginners with little to no dance experience and will allow you to develop a strong foundation in Cuban Salsa in an extremely fun, stress-free atmosphere. In each 90-minute class of the four week series, students focus on developing dance fundamentals including rhythm, coordination, balance, and the specific technical aspects of Cuban Salsa, including basic steps and turn patterns, partnering technique, and the fundamental motions of Casino and Rueda de Casino. Students will also learn social dancing etiquette, floorcraft, and partner <a>safety in</a> an extremely warm, relaxed, social and fun environment. If you can walk, you can do this, so let your friends with two left feet know!

PRICE
-For First Time members & their guests, 1st Class: ONLY $10, 50% OFF!!!
Normally $20 Drop-In!
-Level 1 full month package of 4 Classes: ONLY $60
that's 4 classes (6 hours total) for the price of 3!!!

LOCATION
Adelante Studios
25 West 31st Street between Broadway & 5th Avenue
2nd Floor - Grand Ballroom (3,000 sq ft!)

Nearby Subways: 34th St Station on B, D, F, M, N, Q, R, & PATH trains.
*Can't find us? Call[masked] and we'll point you in the right direction.

All classes are taught by both a male, Chris, and female, Nayelli, so women can easily follow another woman while men are following a man at the same time! They have over 15-years of training, teaching, performing, and traveling to Cuba to collaborate with the very best in the Salsa world. Feel free to contact them at any time for additional info or if you have any questions.

Chris: [masked] /[masked]

Video link of our group doing Rueda de Casino
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UK02-HTye7k
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cINgMRwiL7Q

For those with previous experience dancing Casino, we offer a Level 2/Intermediate class immediately following Level 1 on Wednesdays at 8:30pm.

Intermediate - Level 2

Wednesdays (September 30th - October 21st):

8:30 - 10:00pm Intermediate Cuban Salsa & Rueda de Casino - Level 2

This progressive, 90-min class is geared for those that have danced Cuban Salsa and/or Rueda before and allows you to further solidify, fine-tune, and expand upon the basics covered in Level 1. Here is your opportunity to refresh all of the beginning motions at a pace that is comfortable for you while further building a solid foundation in this exciting, interactive, and fun dance. This high-energy class focuses on combinations, leading and following technique, group moves, styling, body motion, and fun salsa suelta footwork. By the end of the 8-week sequence, you will have all the tools necessary to get out on the dance floor and be fun, fluid, and spontaneous with everything you've learned. *For those that register for Level 2, Level 1 is included as extra practice, free of charge, in your monthly package.*

Sample Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cINgMRwiL7Q

***************************************************

We also offer classes at the advanced level on Tuesdays (September 29th) at Adelante Studios.  Here's the info -

7:00 - 8:30pm Intermediate-transition-to-Advanced Cuban Salsa & Rueda de Casino - Level 3

This progressive series serves as a bridge class for intermediate dancers who have already completed Level 2 and are ready to step up their game. The focus is on technique, as we will provide you with insights on what advanced dancers are constantly attending to while engaging with their partner. Each 90-minute session is broken down into 3 parts - Suelta (Footwork & Movement), Casino (One-on-One Partnering), and Rueda - all danced to rhythmically dense Timba. By the end of this 8-week series, you will be equipped with all the necessary tools to make a seamless transition into the advanced level. *For those that register for Level 3, Levels 1 & 2 are included as extra practice, free of charge, in your monthly package.*

Sample Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rSHUoyjfxlA

Location:

Adelante Studios
25 W 31st Street between Broadway and 5th Avenue
2nd Floor
Grand Ballroom

Nearby Subways: 34th St Station on B, D, F, M, N, Q, R, & PATH trains.

*Can't find our room? Call[masked] and we'll point you in the right direction.
results.how_to_find_us: Take elevators to the 2nd Floor & make a left. We have the entire studio loft space, complete with brand new, clean rooms, hardwood floors, mirrors, 12’ ceiling, A/C, & sound system.

results.description:
EVERY Wednesday Night!

New York City's hottest open mic in the heart of Queens' cultural mecca and in the homiest underground spot around - one level downstairs in the Q4 Hotel in Long Island City.

Produced by the long-running independent performance series, The Inspired Word (http://inspiredwordnyc.com), which has featured Grammy winners, American Idol finalists, Golden Globe Award winners, Emmy nominated actors, and HBO Def Poetry stars, this open mic is open to ALL types of performing artists - musicians, comedians, poets, fiction/nonfiction writers, playwrights, spoken word artists, storytellers, performance artists, dancers, etc.

20 performance slots, 6-minute time limit for anything spoken, 7 minutes for anything musical. **Note to musicians: If you have backing tracks, bring them on an mp3 player or smartphone. Note to piano/keyboard players: You must bring your own keyboard.**

We are dedicated to celebrating the best of Queens' performing arts and developing a warm local artistic community. 

NO AGE RESTRICTIONS.

*****

When: Every Wednesday Night

Where: Q4 Hotel
http://www.q4hotel.com/

29-09 Queens Plaza N.
Long Island City, NYC

Time: 7pm sharp

Admission: $7 online for solo performer or audience member, $10 at the door

This is a very popular open mic. You can pay online or at the door, but we STRONGLY suggest you purchase a ticket in advance to guarantee a performance slot.

*****

By subway, take the E to Queens Plaza, N/Q/7 to Queensboro Plaza.

*****

Produced by Mike Geffner Presents The Inspired Word

http://inspiredwordnyc.com

"It's not just a series...It's a movement."

#SupportLiveArtsNYC
results.how_to_find_us: Go to front desk and ask where the downstairs stairwell is to the open mic.
results.name: Wednesday Night Open Mic @ Q4 Hotel - Music, Poetry, Comedy, Spoken Word

results.description:
Mindful Astoria: Wednesday Meditation Gathering

Join us on Wednesday nights for meditation and conversation about mindfulness. Learn how to bring mindfulness into daily life, and how to establish, maintain, and deepen a personal mindfulness practice.

Each class will consist of instruction in different forms of mindfulness meditation, and time for group discussion and connecting with the community. Depending on the week, the teacher may give a talk or share a reading about a related topic.

Check out our group guidelines.

Teacher for this night's gathering: Emily Herzlin 

Emily (also the MeetUp group organizer) is a writer, editor, and teacher. She has taught creative writing and mindfulness meditation at Columbia University, The Interdependence Project, Adelphi University, GreenspaceNYC, and Mission to (dit)Mars. Emily has been practicing mindfulness meditation for ten years, and trained in Mindfulness Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) through the Center for Mindfulness at UMass Medical School. She is also a graduate of the Yearlong Immersion and Teacher Training program at the Interdependence Project, where she currently teaches MBSR and a monthly contemplative writing workshop. 

Mindful Astoria

Every Wednesday, 7-8:30pm at the Astoria First Presbyterian Church.

All classes are drop-in, but RSVP. $5-$10 at the door to cover meetup dues and support the teachers and the Astoria Presbyterian Church. *Note that no one will be turned away for lack of funds. If you cannot afford the suggested donation, please give what you are able.

Email any questions to Emily Herzlin at [masked].

Looking forward to deepening practice and strengthening mindful community with you all!
results.how_to_find_us: The church is located at 23-35 Broadway, between Crescent St. and 23rd St. It is on the north side of Broadway, just past Trade Fair and Synergy Fitness. There is an awning over the front door. The church shares the space with Art House Astoria.
results.name: Mindful Astoria: Wednesday Meditation Gathering

results.description:
QueensJS is going strong with our 15th meeting on Wednesday, October 7th, at our usual haunt, Raven’s Head Pub in Astoria on 38th & Broadway, just around the corner from the Steinway MR stop and 7 short streets over from the Broadway NQ stop. 


Your evening infotainment includes:

• Angus Grieve-Smith (@grvsmth) will be "Using AngularJS to Help the Spies Read Your Email"

• Sam Agnew (@SagnewShreds) will be blowing off his NES cartridges for his talk.


• Mariko Kosaka (@kosamari) will implore "Everybody write your own parser!"


QueensJS expects all speakers and attendees to follow the JSConf code of conduct.

RSVPs, due to limited seating, will cost $5. All proceeds go towards charities that work to increase code literacy among NYC youth. There are no refunds, but you are more than welcome to transfer tickets.

If you would like to sponsor or speak at one of our events, please email us at organizers at queensjs dot com!

To CJK Experts and Native Speakers:

We practice like this (including, but not limited to):

Session 1 (7pm-8pm): Interpretation methods practice

For example, words, phrases or sentences interpretation, target language repeating, shadowing and summarization, etc.

We set two tables to practice Chinese and Korean separately (Japanese is on hiatus due to low membership). The session is basically for intermediate & above Chinese and Korean learners.

Session 2 (8pm-9pm): Topic-based speaking practice

Summary, speak or discuss the topic you are provided or you have prepared by your target language (Chinese & Korean).

Also, everybody can move to any table as they want.

If you would like to practice English, please join our regular Saturday meetup generously hosted by Carl.

Looking forward to practicing with you all!

Organizers

results.description:
Back again . . . the group was on hiatus for a while as I was traveling in France and Spain.  So I thought I’d start up the group again by featuring one of the regions I visited: Languedoc in southern France.

Along with neighboring Roussillon, with which the Languedoc is often linked, this is the largest single wine-producing region in the world, and accounts for a third of all French wine output.  And this is in spite of the fact that production has been reduced in recent decades—a vine-pull plan in the ‘90s, aiming to reduce a glut of surplus wine, eliminated lesser vineyards, and in those that remained there was a new focus on better production methods and higher quality varietals.  New regulations limit the varieties that can be used in AOC wines and specify maximum percentages in blends.   

The best Languedoc wines are rich and robust, not unlike southern Rhône wines, with notes of spice and herbal garrigue, the scrubby vegetation one finds on the arid hillsides.

MAJOR APPELLATIONS

Côteaux du Languedoc – This is a catch-all appellation (in the process of being renamed simply “Languedoc”) that covers the entire region, and can be applied to wines that do not fall under more specific regional appellations while adhering to AOC Languedoc regulations.  Wines must be made from at least two grape varieties, and no more than 40 percent can be either Carignan or Cinsault (considered inferior to “improving” varietals such as Syrah, Grenache, or Mourvedre).  Names of superior subregions can be appended to the Languedoc appellation, such as St-Drézery or Pic-St-Loup (the latter allowing no more than 10 percent Carignan).  We will be trying two Côteaux du Languedoc wines, one each from Pic-St-Loup and St-Drézery, made by the prestigious Château Puech-Haut, which since its founding in 2000 has become one of the star producers of the region.

IGP Pays de Hérault – This is a “vin de pays” category that covers wines made anywhere in the Hérault department that do not conform to AOC regulations.  This could include wines made from otherwise disallowed Bordeaux varietals, which can be among the most prestigious wines made in the Languedoc.  We will be trying a Bordeaux blend made by Mas de Daumas Gassac, the so-called “Grand Cru” of the Languedoc.  (I was able to visit this winery and tried this wine in their tasting room.  Photos of vineyards and of grapes being transported into the winery.)

Picpoul de Pinet – This is the signature white wine of the Languedoc, the grape’s name derived from “pique-poul,” meaning “sting the lip,” an appropriate descriptor for this brightly acidic wine (I’ve always thought of it as a southern Muscadet).  We will be trying the only Picpoul ever to have earned the coup de coeur from the French Guide Hachette des Vins, that publication’s highest honor. 

Corbières –  This is the largest appellation in the Languedoc and one of the largest in France, and the widely varying terroirs result in wines of equally various styles and quality levels.  Most of the production is red (made from at least two grapes, of which Grenache, Syrah, and Mourvedre must make up at least 50 percent of the blend), but small quantities of fine white wine are made.  We’ll be trying a Corbières white made up of Grenache Blanc and Grenache Gris.     

Minervois – Another large appellation, centered on the ancient and picturesque village of Minerve (photo).  Minervois has seen considerable investment, with a corresponding increase in the prestige of their wines.  The wines must be blends, made up of at least 60 percent Grenache, Syrah, and/or Mourvedre.  We will be trying a well-priced blend of mostly Grenache that was inspired by the winemaker’s ten years spent in Châteauneuf-du-Pape.

Faugères – A highly regarded appellation with vineyards situated on steep, south-facing slopes.  Yields are low and the growing season is long, resulting in rich, southern Rhône–style wines.  We will try an example by one of Faugères’ best winemakers, Léon Barral, whose wine (unusually these days) consists of 50 percent old-vines Carignan. 

We’ll be returning to one of our old reliables, Harper’s in Dobbs Ferry.

http://harpersonmain.com/

2013 Domaine Sainte Croix Corbières Blanc La Serre  $25

Not reviewed.  From the winemaker: “Pale light straw with green lights. On the nose, honeyed grapefruit, brioche, wild asparagus thyme and sherbet. A full palate of fresh lemon and lime, gunflint minerality, fresh butter, herbal notes, bright acidity. Long intense finish.” 60% old-vine Grenache Blanc, 40% old-vine Grenache Gris.

2013 Domaine Reine Juliette Picpoul-de-Pinet Terres Rouges  $12

Guide Hachette des Vins 2015 ★★ Coup de Coeur – Un coup de coeur “historique,” le premier pour la toute nouvelle appellation Picpoul-de-Pinet.  Une cuvée qui s’annonce sans réserve par un bouquet intense, riche, et complexe d’agrumes (citron, pomelo) et de fruits exotiques (mangue, fruit de la passion).  Le palais se révèle ample, frais comme il se doit et très fruité: agrumes confits, pêche, et cette touche iodée qui signe son origine.  (A historic coup de coeur, the first for the new appellation Picpoul-de-Pinet. A wine that unreservedly promises an intense bouquet—rich, complex, with citrus [lemon, grapefruit] and exotic fruits [mango, passion fruit]. The palate is ample, fresh as it should be, and very fruity: candied citrus, peach, and a touch of iodine signifying its origin.)

2013 Château Puech-Haut Côteaux du Languedoc Pic-St-Loup la Closerie du Pic  $24

Wine Advocate 93-95 – Equal parts Syrah and Grenache, with the Syrah aged in barrel (some new) and the Grenache in concrete tank. It exhibits terrific amounts of cassis and black raspberry fruit to go with additional notes of pepper, smoked meats, violets and crushed rock. Full-bodied, beautifully pure, layered and elegant, yet rich and textured, it should drink nicely on release, yet also evolve gracefully.

2011 Château Puech-Haut Côteaux du Languedoc Saint Drézéry Bosc Nègre  $52

Wine Advocate 95 – Roughly 80% Mourvèdre and 20% Grenache with the Mourvèdre aged in new barrels and the Grenache in tank.  The 2011 Côteaux du Languedoc Saint Drézéry Bosc Nègre (which translates to "Black Wood" and named after the woods located near the vineyard) is an inky-colored, big and structured effort. Assorted dark fruits, mineral, earth, violets and chocolate nuances are the core, and it hits the palate with full-bodied richness, fabulous mid-palate depth and serious structure that emerges on the finish.

2013 Mas de Daumas Gassac Rouge IGP Pays de l'Hérault  $37

Jancis Robinson 16.5+/20 – Dark crimson. Lifted spicy nose with firm tannins. Quite rich and sleek. Lots of energy. Tannins quite insistent. 72% Cabernet Sauvignon, 5.4% Merlot, 5.3% Tannat, 3.8% Cabernet Franc, 2.5% Malbec, 2% Pinot Noir, 9% variétés rares.

2011 L'Oustal Blanc Minervois Giocoso  $20

Wine Advocate 93 – The 2011 Minervois Giocoso (65% Grenache, 20% Syrah, 15% Carignan) offers an up-front, gorgeously fruited feel, with cassis, dried spices, licorice and hints of baker’s chocolate to go with full-bodied richness on the palate. It is a knockout effort to drink over the coming 5-7 years or so. 

2010 Domaine Léon Barral Faugères Jadis  $50

Wine Advocate 94 – The 2010 Faugères Jadis comes from south-facing slopes and is a blend of 50% Carignan, 30% Syrah, and 20% Grenache that spends 24-26 months in 10% new barrels. Layered and perfumed on the nose, with fabulous plum pit, leather, violets, assorted spices and dusty minerality, it is full-bodied, seamless, and elegant on the palate, with impressive polish to its tannin. Concentrated with excellent texture and length, it will have 10-15 years of longevity.
results.name: Languedoc

results.description:
The format of course stays the same: 5 minutes to show off your hack, and 5 minutes for the audience to applaud, cry, laugh, inquiry, snore, chew, stand, sit, dance, grow, interact, etc. But, of course, we hope that the audience provides lots of great feedback and asks interesting questions (probably while sitting, though dancing audience members are certainly free to participate as well)!


Show us what you've got! But, remember, no startup pitches, no work related projects[0], and no deckware! See you at Meetup! RSVPs open Wednesday at 12 PM, Noon.

If you're interested in presenting, this is the url to use:

•  http://j.mp/PresentHackAtRound35


NOTE: All money raised from the $5 RSVP fee will of course be donated to an organization in need. (Last time we donated it to the Software Freedom Conservancy! https://sfconservancy.org/)

[0]: Let us clarify the "no job projects" rule. We want to promote the projects that people do in their spare time, for fun, or utility, and not the kinds of projects that are only applicable to people who work in your company, or your direct clients. On the other hand, there may be a project that you've built primarily at work, that solves a *general* problem that your company has allowed you to release with a libre license-- this is usually fine.


Questions We Expect To Be Asked

Do I have to pay if I sign up to present?

* No! Anyone who even so much as submits a presentation proposal, whether or not you're actually selected, will *not* be charged. If you want to present, you already have "skin in the game." We're trying to make everyone who wants to attend invested enough to *actually* show up.

I have a fixed income / am a student / just simply don't have $5 to spare, can I still come?

* Please contact [masked], let us know, and we'll take care of you! We definitely want to be as inclusive as possible, and if money is your only problem we won't let it get in the way of you joining us!

results.description:
Join us for Summer Tennis.

Check in at Clubhouse for court assignment upon arrival, then play under the lights 'til 10:00pm at this beautiful wooded park*.

Please remember to check in with the clubhouse to reserve a court. Players need to reserve a court with at least one other player present and should be a Hudson County resident with ID.

Mention to the court staff that you are with the Meetup group and ask that they keep us together if possible (3 courts).

Make sure you only use 3-4 of the same numbered balls. Public courts do not allow use of more than 6 balls per court.

Also please try to use the same age balls as it will help you improve your game. And remember to bring plenty of water!

You can find each other in the waiting area and/or looking on the courts. It would help if you make a mental note of the profile picture of those attending. I will provide my cell # for RSVP's so we can find each other. Please also bear in mind that we are usually on more than one court - they are available on a first-come, first-serve basis. You should locate other players and grab a court when you arrive.

Although we won't enforce attendance, please keep your rsvp updated because others are looking to find partners to hit with. Remove your name from the list if you are not planning to attend.

Inclement weather cancels the event.

If you have any questions, feel free to email the organizer.

Thank you all for this great group!

*Free for Hudson County residents. Those outside of Hudson County may play as a guest of the resident players to avoid a possible $10 fee to play.
results.how_to_find_us: Be sure to check the rsvp list for other player's photos. I will send my contact info before the event.

results.description:
We'll meet in front of MP Taverna for a loop run along Buckout St to Mercy College, through Dobbs Ferry and back. Afterward, everyone is welcome to stop in at MP Taverna for drinks and/or eats.

Details about the run

Route: As the sun is setting earlier now, we’ll leave promptly at 7 pm from the parking lot in front of MP Taverna. We'll head south on Buckout St and Half Moon Lane and then we'll use the little wooded short cut to the Ardsley Train Station. We'll run past the station, veer right onto the lit walking path into the Mercy College campus, and through the campus, exiting on to Broadway at Landing Dr. We'll head south on Broadway and then we'll weave through Ardsley Park, taking Langdon to Belmont to Field Terrace to Osceola, before exiting right onto Broadway for the run back to Irvington. A tentative route map is available <a>here</a>. 

Modifications for a shorter/slower-paced run: At various points runners can divert east toward Broadway and head back to Irvington.

Water/Bag Storage: There are no water fountains along the route, so bring a water bottle if you need one while running. I’ll bring water and cups for after the run. There’s no bag storage, so leave belongings at home or in your car.


Location: MP Taverna parking lot (One Bridge St, Irvington, NY)

Join our Facebook group to post pictures or message other members.

General advice & guidelines for our regular meetup runs

• RSVP if you are going. If your plans change, simply change your RSVP.

• There is no bag storage, so please bring only what you plan to run with.

• All regular runs are rain or shine, unless the weather is actually dangerous.

• If you arrive late, can’t find the start location, miss us for any reason, run anyway!

• If you missed RSVP deadline, and know our starting point, feel free to join us on the day – just this one time :)

Feel free to contact me either via my meetup account or at [masked] if you have any questions.
results.name: Irvington to Dobbs Ferry Loop

results.description:
This event is proudly brought to you by Soccer Beyond!

Learn more on SoccerBeyond.com or Facebook.com/SoccerBeyond.

Details - Fun, interactive, effective.

60min. This is a Coed Soccer Lesson. Please bring a ball if you have. Sneakers, running and turf shoes are fine. Bring some water or sports drink and maybe sun blocker. Please note our Waiver of Liability and 24hr Cancellation Policy below. More details follow.

Rain or Shine - If you don't hear from us, the session is on!

Our sessions will be held as scheduled if weather allows. Thunder or snow and ice are among the reasons for sessions to be canceled/ moved. BUT: Don't make assumptions - you will always get notified if a class is canceled/ moved. As the weather changes quickly in NYC, occasionally we may make the final decision about 90min prior to session start. If you don't hear from us, the session is on!

Cancelled/ Moved Sessions - You will always get notified!

Every time we have to cancel a session, if possible, we move it to the same day and time of the following week. In this case, all players keep their spots. Please email us prior to the rescheduled event, if you can't make and wish a refund or credit. The 24 hours cancellation policy applies. You will always get notified if a class is canceled/ moved.

Requesting a Refund

To request a refund 1) change your status to "not going" and 2) send us a note with the Paypal transaction number related to the payment for the respective session. Refunds are processed once a week - please be patient.


24 Hours Cancellation Policy

A full refund/ credit will be given if cancellation is received at least 24 hours prior to lesson start. Full payment is required thereafter. Our cancellation policy also applies to package holders.


Waiver of Liability and Hold Harmless Agreement

By RSVP'ing for this event you certify that you are physically fit such as you are able to participate in this program. You therewith voluntarily release CoachFrankNYC/ Soccer Beyond, LLC from any and all liability resulting from or arising out of your participation and/ or receipt of instruction. You read and agree to the WAIVER OF LIABILITY AND HOLD HARMLESS AGREEMENT to be found on SoccerBeyond.com/pages/waiver.

Please let us know if you have any questions or suggestions.

Coach Frank

results.description:
Class Description: Hip Hop focuses on rhythm, syncopation and stage presence. Derived from a combination of jazz funk and street jazz, this style of dance requires high energy, attention to detail and an understanding of complex rhythms.

*Each week we will feature a new focus and various reoccurring or new instructors from all around the plant. African, Popping, Locking, Beat Boy, and Music Video Choreography. This helps keep it fresh so we learn the best.

results.description:
Pearson is in the middle of a global transformation, changing the way products are built and investment decisions are made. We are hosting monthly meetups at the NYC HQ on different topics, but will spend time at the end of each meetup answering questions about how we are actually implementing leanstartup at scale. Leanstartup is a registered trademark of Eric Ries. 

Innovation is a dirty word. We will spend a few minutes talking about what it is, then the meetup will center around who should be in charge of:


• New ideas vs old ideas

• Execution vs exploration 

• Question marks vs cash cows 

• Vision vs hindsight

We will run the meetup in the Lean Coffee format, so the participants will have ultimate control of the agenda and amount of time spent on each topic.
results.how_to_find_us: 9th Floor Soho/Noho room.
results.name: Whose job is it to inn%vat@?

group.name: Lean Startup in the Enterprise Meetup

results.description:
In this 2 hour workshop, you will learn the basics of working with leather and create your own personalized card holder wallet to keep.


If you’ve never worked with leather before, this is a perfect introduction! Techniques include studding or hand sewing the wallet together and are taught by English shoemaker and leather worker, Elizabeth Dunn.


All materials are provided, including a wide range of leathers to choose from and optional personal embossing.


Class limit is 6 people and the class may be cancelled if there is low enrollment.


Sign Up Today! https://goo.gl/7rmq7U
results.name: Leather Wallet Workshop

results.description:
D&D Encounters is an episodic-format event designed to allow new players to join in and learn D&D in a casual, pick-up game. Seasoned players with erratic schedules can easily hop in and out of Encounters; unlike a traditional campaign, DMs and players will rotate, resulting in a dynamic game experience. We are using the latest edition of D&D (5e) and each session lasts about 3-4 hours, easily fitting into your work or school schedule, and presents a new and exciting challenge each week. The $10 fee covers your use of the playspace, though committing to 10 weeks grants the player a discount.


We're always on the lookout for DM talent for this season-- volunteers keep programs like this one alive! However, more important than veteran DMs, Encounters is a place where even new players should feel comfortable testing out the DMing waters. Every Saturday we provide our DMs with that week's "adventure chunk", a set of 2-3 encounters in one simple, easy-to-read packet. This bite-sized DMing format is ideal for new DMs and veterans who don't have the time to create an entire campaign from scratch, and allow lots of room for alterations and improvisations as the DM sees fit. DMs who volunteer their time do not pay the $10 fee, and receive a steep discount on our D&D related products.


For our first session, we will be creating level 1 characters and running a brief "test run" of our new adventurers as they get their footing the world of the Forgotten Realms. It won't be long before we're on the road to great deeds, so you won't want to miss this great opportunity to get to know your fellow heroes!

Please private message Timm with any questions regarding DMing, the event, or anything else RPG related!
results.name: Brooklyn Strategist Presents: D&D Encounters, Rage of Demons

group.name: The NYC Dungeons & Dragons Meetup Group

Whether it's a beloved side project, a language you want to learn, or a baffling question you want to ask in friendly company, everything is welcome.

There will be food, beverage, and unabashed geekery.

* No recruiters.

results.description:
What is a civic hacknight?

This is a weekly project night is for technologists, designers, developers, data scientists, map makers, and activists who are working on "civic technology" projects. Consider this to be a study hall or office hours to improve you and the city.

This night is for those who want to: 

 * work on projects
 * start a new project, or find one to join
 * get feedback from experts 
 * learn about tools for local empowerment, open data, and open government

Bring your laptop, power supply, ideas, projects, maps, data, and questions. Collectively, we will try to answer them.

-=-=-

Hacknight resources:

For first timers trying to get the most out of the night, you should bring your laptop, power supply, and watch the following videos -- Civic Hacking 101 & Civic Hacking 102.

 * Check out conversations on talk.beta.nyc
 * Join a real time conversation via slack.beta.nyc
 * Data tools: Data.Beta.NYC, data resources, maps, & tools 
 * Community projects in process - projects.beta.nyc

-=-=-

Projects & presentations:

We keep the “formal” part of the evening down to a minimum: announcements, meet your neighbor, etc. After, we will have a number of people present, specific projects, and have some skills share / education. 

Community Projects:


 * What are YOU working on?
 * Hop over to talk and tell us.

-=-=-

Event Partners:

The Code for America Brigade program is an international network of people committed to using their voices and hands, in collaboration with local governments, to make their cities better.

Microsoft Civic aims to collaboratively address the most pressing community challenges through the hyper-local creation, deployment, and evangelism of civic technology.

Accela provides civic engagement solutions for government. Accela’s solutions uniquely address the diverse needs of their constituents by making publicly available information more accessible. The Accela Civic Platform includes solutions for land management, asset management, licensing and case management, legislative management, right of way management, citizen relationship management, recreation and resource management, environmental health and safety.

-=-=-

Note about the venue:

You should RSVP with the name that appears on a photo ID. In order to give building security an RSVP list, RSVPs will close at 4:00 PM the day of the event. If you miss this deadline, most of the time security is nice and will let you in.

BetaNYC is committed to hosting safe and open events for all. By attending this event you are committing yourself to BetaNYC's Code of Conduct and Anti-Harassment Policy.
results.how_to_find_us: Use the front staircase; we'll be in the "coworking" space.
results.name: Civic Hacknight at Civic Hall

results.description:
Dive into a magical world of hilarity and villainy with Nimona. Fight dragons, shapeshift, and thwart nemeses in this critically acclaimed web comic turned fantasy graphic novel.  

// Book
Nimona, Noelle Stevenson
The graphic novel debut from rising star Noelle Stevenson, based on her beloved and critically acclaimed web comic, which Slate awarded its Cartoonist Studio Prize, calling it "a deadpan epic."

Nemeses! Dragons! Science! Symbolism! All these and more await in this brilliantly subversive, sharply irreverent epic from Noelle Stevenson. Nimona is an impulsive young shapeshifter with a knack for villainy. Lord Ballister Blackheart is a villain with a vendetta. As sidekick and supervillain, Nimona and Lord Blackheart are about to wreak some serious havoc. Their mission: prove to the kingdom that Sir Ambrosius Goldenloin and his buddies at the Institution of Law Enforcement and Heroics aren't the heroes everyone thinks they are.

But as small acts of mischief escalate into a vicious battle, Lord Blackheart realizes that Nimona's powers are as murky and mysterious as her past. And her unpredictable wild side might be more dangerous than he is willing to admit. 


// Location
Ninth Ward, 180 2nd Avenue
Join us at this dark and cozy medieval themed pub for 2 for 1 happy hour until 8pm.
Cocktails $13 / Beer $6- $8 / Menu available here.


// Dues
This book club does not require annual membership dues. However, we kindly ask that attendees bring $2 cash to the event to cover Meetup fees and the occasional book giveaway! (I also accept Venmo.)

// Book Giveaway
One lucky book club attendee will receive a copy of Wytches by Scott Snyder! To enter: attend this meetup, bring $2 event dues, and fill out a card with your name and phone number. Wytches is a contender for next month’s HORROR book club.


// Next Month
Join us next month for a month of HORROR as we read Through the Woods by Emily Carroll.
results.how_to_find_us: Booth reservation towards the back under the name Anastasia.
results.name: Graphic Novel #1 – Nimona by Noelle Stevenson

results.description:
You're invited to join us for this weekly opportunity to sharpen your drawing skills! This session is open to sketchers of all levels.

What makes our sessions different? 

• We start on time in a large, clean, well-lit space. 

• Sketchers can concentrate because our room is quiet while the model is posing.

• We have coffee and cookies at the long break. 

• We finish on time so you can be headed home at 9:00 p.m sharp! 

• (Latecomers can be seated at a break.)


• This is a two hour drawing session to work from a live (nude) model.  

• We start with short 2 minute poses and work up to a 20 minute pose by the end of the session. We take a 5 minute break every 20 minutes. 


• There are seats for everyone tables and several light weight easels. 


• Access to a sink is available for watercolor artist.

• Bring your own materials (no oil or acrylic paint and no sprays please.)

As always if you have any questions please feel free to email me. I look forward to seeing you there. 

Simon
results.how_to_find_us: Ask for the drawing class on the second floor.
results.name: Live Model Drawing - Union Square

results.description:
Welcome all writers and thank you for joining!

Our agenda is as follows:

7:30-8:00 - set writing goals for upcoming week & share obstacles

8:00-8:30 - provide feedback for the chosen pieces & choose new works for following meeting

8:30-9:00 - craft discussion

9:00-9:15 - wind down & poll group

How to receive feedback:

IF you would like to be critiqued, you must attend at least one meetup to become familiar with and understand the format of the meetings. Attendees are expected to eventually submit work for feedback. In the preceding meetup we choose two writers to be critiqued. The third work is a backup if time permits. Please read them all as well as the craft essays in the "Files" section under "More" tab.

How to post:

1) Post only if you have been chosen to be critiqued and by Friday at noon. (For critique outside of meetups please post in "Pages" in the menu above.)

2) Before Posting: Long-Form Length: 3,000 words or 10 pgs max (can be shorter)

If submitting poems, max 3 a person

Double-spaced (unless for aesthetics)

11-12 point font (no smaller or larger)

Number your pages

*The organizing team maintains the right to remove pieces from circulation

3) Post in Files under More tab with this description:

- Name

- Meetup date

- Description of your work

- Type of feedback you would like

- Fiction or non-fiction specified

(As description box allows.)

When critiquing: (Always use "I" when critiquing)

1) Each person is allotted 5 mins. The writer is also allotted 5 mins to respond after everyone has spoken.

2) Share what worked and/or what you liked/ enjoyed and why.

3) Offer suggestions/ constructive criticism for improvement.

*Caffé Bene has a large assortment of coffees and teas and tasty things to eat. Please pay for your space with a purchase from the establishment.

*A listing of contests and magazines to submit to can be found on our Discussions page

See you there,
results.name: Critique, Goal Setting, & Craft Discussion

results.description:
WOMEN ONLY EVENT. Meeting a MAN in NYC is not the easiest of tasks. What makes it even tougher is if you don't have a reliable friend to help navigate the NYC single scene.


Come meet your new BFF at our Ladies Networking Night!

Every single woman needs a dependable friend, equally motivated to go out with you to parties, clubs, bars, and everything else as single women we don't want to hit "solo." 

Meet up to 30 other "single and fabulous" women (30s & 40s) at our upscale speed networking event.  Also, enjoy $4 beer and $5 wine drink specials. 

We'll start you off in groups where you'll get to meet 3-4 women at a time and then we'll transition to a less formal mixer where you all can mingle at your leisure.

This is a PREPAY ONLY EVENT. NO tickets sold at the door.

1st 5 women to get tickets save $5 by using discount code "BFF" at checkout ($20). MUST BUY TICKET IN ADVANCE - 

https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/wing/dates/Oct-07-2015_at_0730PM

Why does your RSVP say +30?  This is a multi-Meetup group event. This page only shows a small portion of the actual attendees. 30+ women will be attending (ages 30s & 40s)

Come meet your new BFF at our Ladies Networking Night!

Every single woman needs a dependable friend, equally motivated to go out with you to parties, clubs, bars, and everything else as single women we don't want to hit "solo." 

Meet up to 30 other "single and fabulous" women (30s & 40s) at our upscale speed networking event.  Also, enjoy $4 beer and $5 wine drink specials. 

We'll start you off in groups where you'll get to meet 3-4 women at a time and then we'll transition to a less formal mixer where you all can mingle at your leisure. 

This is a PREPAY ONLY EVENT. NO tickets sold at the door.

1st 5 women to get tickets save $5 by using discount code "BFF" at checkout  ($20)  MUST BUY TICKET IN ADVANCE - 

https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/wing/dates/Oct-07-2015_at_0730PM

Why does your RSVP say +30?  This is a multi-Meetup group event. This page only shows a small portion of the actual attendees.  30+ women will be attending (ages 30s & 40s) 

GET TICKETS HERE - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/wing/dates/Oct-07-2015_at_0730PM

results.description:
This is a casual in-store wine tasting event, usually on the 1st Wednesday of every month, featuring a selection of 3 wines and light refreshments.

Join the Sipper's Delight Wine Tasting Social Club at The Artisan Collective for wine sipping and socializing in a fun and unpretentious environment.  Each month we will taste and discuss three new wines.  This event is a great way to develop your wine tasting skills, learn about different wines and meet other wine enthusiasts!

Upcoming Tasting Dates & Themes

• 7/1:  Drink Local (NY & NJ Wines)

• 8/5:  South African Wines

• 9/2 - Italian Wines Part I (Northern Italy)

• 10/7 - Italian Wines Part II (Southern Italy & Islands)

Admission: $10

Directions:  NJ Transit to Newark Penn Station or Broad Street Station.

From Newark Penn Station: Take the Light Rail to NJ PAC/Center Street and walk approximately 2 blocks West to the corner of Central & Halsey Street (cross Broad Street). Turn left onto Halsey and walk to the Artisan Collective, located at 25 Halsey Street.

From Broad Street: Take the Light Rail to Washington Park.  Turn right onto Washington Street, then left onto Halsey Street.  Walk 1.5 blocks South on Halsey Street (cross Central Ave) to the Artisan Collective, located at 25 Halsey Street.
results.name: Wine Tasting Wednesdays

group.name: Sipper's Delight Wine Tasting Social Club - NJ/NY

results.description:
We will discuss what gives you energy and what takes it away and where is most it being spent. Of course we will also check in and see how we are doing with our small steps to our big goal of being unstuck. 

First time is free, all others $10/meeting.

Hope to see you there!
results.name: How Are You Spending Your Energy?

results.description:
We'll meet at the Battery Park City ball fields for some pickup soccer. If there's an event going on, we'll work around it.

No-show policy: 1 no-show--> 1 RSVP cancelled, 2 no-shows--> Removal from group
results.name: Pickup soccer in Battery Park City

group.name: New York  - Battery Park City - Pickup soccer 5v5 - Wed

venue.address_1: At the Rose Academy of Ballet
venue.name: 70-11 Austin Street 2nd Floor

results.description:
Salsa Class-

This is a advanced beginner class that teaches the basics of NYC Style Salsa on 2. The class will begin with a warm-up to build comfort with basic footwork, turns, musicality and technique. Students will then learn a flashy dance pattern to dance together at their next Salsa event!

* The class will include a 10 minute social dance session in order to encourage dancers to practice their new material, along with building comfort and confidence in a fun and relaxed atmosphere!

Participation fee: $15 per person or $50 for 4-week session 

This is a weekly class that is regularly attended, the attendance shown for this event does not reflect the full attendance of the class, space is limited - Please RSVP if you would like to join us! 

New to our studio? Try your first class for FREE!

Like us on Facebook and E-mail us your full name along with which class you would like to attend, and your first class is on us!

You can find more information about our classes and events by visiting our Web-site, Spirare Dance Studio.

You can also find us on Facebook, Spirare Dance.
results.how_to_find_us: Take the E,F,M,R Train to 71st Continental Ave

results.description:
Become a protector, hero or heroine, what does that mean? We can all develop the great qualities that embody such a title through the daily practice of the 6 Perfections.  

Join us as we grow our mindfulness and our practices of generosity, kindness, patience, effort, concentration and wisdom. These time tested meditations will ignite our hero or heroine, we will become the great protector, one who is able to bring enormous relief and transformation to our world. 

Meditation is the means to ignite the hero or heroine within.....
results.name: Wednesdays in October ~ "Calling the Hero or Heroine within" ~ Kadam Peter

results.description:
Our typical agenda: - We orient new visitors and then chat a bit, as by sharing what's new or good in our lives. - Then we meditate together by chanting mantra followed by the beautiful sounds of the gong - And finally we share thoughts and questions, learning something new sometimes, generally supporting each other best we can.

Note that we meet every Wednesday, 7:30 to 9 pm, and every Saturday, 2 to 3:30 pm -- except for the first Saturday of the month, when we begin our meeting at 5 pm followed by an informal potluck social. If you are planning on staying for the potluck, be sure to visit www.perfectpotluck.com to enter your food selection. The website will help you decide what food to contribute to the potluck to make sure we have a healthy, balanced meal.

By the way, the meetup page may show only a few members planning to attend a particular meeting. That's because many people attend regularly and don't bother to RSVP for each meeting.   We never have only a few members at a meeting. A dozen or more usually attend each meeting. The special potluck meetings we hold the first Saturday of each month has an average attendance of two dozen people.

Call Merrill or Mataji anytime you have questions:[masked]-5334.

results.description:
Come join us for our climbing Meetup!!

As usual, everyone is welcome to join in on the fun as long as you're at least 18 years old, whether you’re a complete beginner just looking to give the sport a try or a seasoned veteran that can show the best of us a few new tricks. Bring your friends too, even if they've never tried climbing before. We'll make sure everybody is set up and having a blast. Age and strength don't even matter, everybody has fun.

1st time climbers at The Rock Club get in for FREE! All you have to do is rent a harness and shoes for $9. Returning Meetupers get a discounted daypass rate of $15. And be sure to have a look out at the gym for other special Meetup discounts.

We also host a special Meetup 101 class from 7:30 - 9pm for Meetup members only. When multiple people sign-up for the class you pay only $45 ($15 discount!).

Reserve your spot with the booking button and enter the promo code "Meetup" on the booking page.

IMPORTANT!!  This offer has restrictions. It is only valid for the Weds night Meetup 101 class, you must already be a meetup member and RSVP for the meetup as well (no guests).

If this is your first time climbing just come on in and join the group. There’s no need to take the class just yet. You’ll be able to join other Meetup members who already have their belay certification. This way you’ll be able to get up and on the wall right away! When you decide that you absolutely love climbing (which you will!), then you can sign up for the class the following week.

As a heads up, when you come into the gym, the front desk staff will get you set up with gear and get you in the system. There will also be name tags for everyone. Wear them with pride so everyone knows who’s a part of Meetup!

DETAILS - Please read carefully!

RSVPing and Questions:
If you're attending the belay course you MUST call TRC to reserve your space.
If you have any questions, please email TRC directly: [url][masked][/url]

Time:
The closer to 7pm you arrive, the better. The 101 class starts at 7:30 sharp.

Directions & Transportation:
Please save time and aggravation by getting directions from our website (BEFORE you call or email us for directions :-). If you're coming on Metro North as a group (2 or more people!) we'll pick you up from the train station. Use the message baord to connect with other riders.  Just give us a call to let us know when you'll arrive. Go to the taxi stand in front of the station building!

We're looking forward to seeing you soon!
results.name: Weekly Climbing Meetup - New members climb for free!!
